summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after Townsend was substituted in with only seven minutes left during Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson mocked Townsend on Twitter, referencing his earlier criticism. Merson had previously questioned Townsend's England team inclusion, but Townsend proved him wrong by scoring a stunning equalizer for England in a 1-1 draw against Italy. Despite this, Merson maintained his opinion and Townsend responded on Twitter. Although it seemed their conflict had subsided, Merson again criticized Townsend after Tottenham's match against Burnley.

Chelsea has made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, could join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan if he completes a move to Stamford Bridge. Ogane clarified that Chelsea's interest in Muto is unrelated to their £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, a Japan international with 11 caps and one goal, recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree. Although Chelsea's bid is reportedly around £4 million, Muto has not yet decided whether to join the Premier League club. Muto has been in good form this season, scoring three goals in four games, helping FC Tokyo to third place in the J-League.

A large-scale study published in the journal Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The Finnish researchers analyzed the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and found that those who had taken antibiotics were particularly likely to be overweight. Repeated prescriptions before the age of two further increased the odds of being a fat toddler, with boys being particularly prone to weight gain. The study suggests that antibiotics may contribute to the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic by killing beneficial gut bacteria that normally help process food, potentially leading to increased appetite and more available food for the body. The researchers emphasized the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy.

A Buckingham Palace guard experienced an embarrassing moment when he slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, an incident witnessed by hundreds of tourists. The guard lost his footing, knocked his bearskin off the side of his sentry box, and dropped his rifle. The entire mishap was captured on video by tourist David Meadwell, who was visiting London with his family. The guard quickly recovered and continued with the ceremony, though he appeared embarrassed by the fall. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The passage discusses the remake of the 1977 TV miniseries "Roots," which originally attracted over 100 million viewers. The new version, set to air in 2016, will be a simulcast on A&E networks, including Lifetime and History. LeVar Burton, who played the lead role in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The new series aims to be "original" and "contemporary," drawing more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," and producers will consult African and African-American history scholars for authenticity. The remake seeks to reach both fans of the original and a new generation, especially in light of recent historical and social events such as Barack Obama's presidency and the Oscar win for "12 Years a Slave," as well as ongoing racial tensions in the U.S.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler that Clarence House aides attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, said he was groped and pinned to a chair by a male staff member on his first day working at the Queen Mother’s London residence. The incident left him in tears, prompting him to leave the job immediately. Lawler did not report the incident until last year when inquiries into alleged child sex abuse cover-ups by a VIP paedophile ring began. His complaints were initially ignored, but were eventually passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide denied involvement, claiming he was in Scotland at the time. The Royal Household has pledged full cooperation with any police investigation, though no official comments are being made due to ongoing investigations.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube, features the couple rapping in a car about their surprise conception. The video ends with them sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple mentioned that it took five takes to film the clip and that they made it so distant loved ones could learn about the baby. The video's unexpected popularity has been a pleasant surprise to them. Additionally, Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at an auction held by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, California. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring a black zigzag applique, was worn in several key scenes, including encounters with Rhett Butler and an attack in a shanty town. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray over time. It was part of a larger auction that included over 150 items from the film, all from the private collection of James Tumblin, who had collected over 300,000 pieces of Hollywood memorabilia. Tumblin had originally bought the dress for $20 after spotting it at the Western Costume Company, where it was about to be discarded. Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000.

A two-year-old boy is recovering after falling into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo when his mother dangled him over the edge. The child slipped and fell approximately 10 to 12 feet into the pit, but was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises and was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition. The cheetahs did not attack the boy or his parents. Zoo officials plan to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was temporarily closed following the incident.

A speed camera that had been enforcing a 30mph speed limit on a residential road in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been re-pointed at a house after being non-functional for over two years. All fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands were switched off in March 2013 due to outdated technology. Since then, speed enforcement has been managed by mobile units, fixed cameras on motorways, and traffic officers. The identity of who re-pointed the camera remains unknown, but Birmingham City Council is aware and plans to have an engineer visit the site, potentially removing the camera. The council has no plans to include this camera in a new pilot program using digital technology. The house owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt expressed his readiness and excitement to participate, highlighting Jamaica's strong relay tradition. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure at Bolt's participation, anticipating "sprint magic" during the event. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

The passage highlights several key events involving Neymar and his Barcelona teammates. Neymar and Dani Alves showed their support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending an El Clasico game, where Barcelona narrowly won 85-80. Despite this, Real Madrid remains at the top of their Euro League division by a small margin. Neymar also played a crucial role in Brazil's 1-0 victory over Chile, where he faced tough challenges. Prior to the international break, Barcelona had won their El Clasico match in La Liga, moving them four points clear at the top. Neymar and his teammates are set to return to La Liga to face Celta Vigo, aiming for a treble of trophies. Neymar's sister, Rafaella, attended the basketball match with him and Dani Alves.

Italy is facing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, the Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants and received SOS calls from 20 distressed boats on Monday alone. Save the Children reported that 400 migrants might be missing after a ship carrying 550 capsized off the Libyan coast, but the Italian coast guard could not confirm this incident. There has been a recent increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in Italy in the first three months of 2015. The International Organization for Migration reports that at least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather and unsafe conditions on overcrowded vessels.

Arsene Wenger, Arsenal's manager, is uncertain about the exact reason why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool but is pleased that Sanchez will be playing for Arsenal rather than against them. Sanchez, who was courted by several top clubs, ultimately decided to join Arsenal after the World Cup, making an immediate impact in English football and scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool's interest in Sanchez, which could have influenced negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Despite this, Wenger downplays rumors of a potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and praises Brendan Rodgers' development of Liverpool's team after Suarez's departure and Daniel Sturridge's injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The event will take place at the Lee Valley VeloPark and will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins aims to surpass the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Tickets for the event will go on sale from April 19, with prices starting at £29. Wiggins hopes to inspire others to challenge themselves and aims to achieve a mark that will stand for a long time.

Serena Williams, twice French Open champion, described her hard-fought victory over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as an "eye-opener," revealing she wasn't as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought. Despite Williams' eventual win 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, the US team lost 3-2 overall after Williams and Alison Riske were defeated 6-0, 6-3 in doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, relegating them to World Group II. Williams noted the tough weather conditions and Errani's strong performance, while US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for harder work to return to the elite group next year.

River Plate is interested in signing Radamel Falcao, the Colombian striker who previously played for them from 2001 to 2009. Falcao is currently on loan at Manchester United but has struggled, scoring only four Premier League goals this season. River Plate's vice president Matias Patanian expressed the club's desire to bring Falcao back, stating "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Falcao has recently scored three goals for Colombia, equaling the national team's all-time goalscoring record of 24 goals. During his earlier tenure at River Plate, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a pop star and X Factor finalist, has partnered with the dry shampoo brand Batiste for their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various stylish looks against vibrant city backgrounds, showcasing different hairstyles. The campaign was launched with a TV ad featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about working with Batiste, a product she uses regularly. Mark Hargreaves, her manager, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and the brand, anticipating an exciting 2015.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are shocked and upset by a billboard erected in the city featuring Torres and his dog. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, reads "Thank you for your support, Kenosha." Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful and are calling for its removal, with one friend stating it feels like a thank you for killing Siler. The police association maintains that no offense was intended and that the billboard was meant to thank the community for its support during the difficult time. The investigation into Siler's shooting is ongoing, while the shooting of another man, Terry Knight, by Torres was deemed justified by the District Attorney.

In a clash near the Iran-Pakistan border, eight Iranian border guards were killed by militants who crossed from Pakistan. Iranian forces killed three of the militants in the southeastern town of Negur. The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack, which aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to capture the surviving assailants. Pakistan condemned the attack and assured Iran that it is investigating the incident and will apprehend any militants who fled into Pakistan.

In a recent political discussion in Japan, flamboyant former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki raised the question of whether Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had encountered any extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Defense Minister Gen Nakatani responded to Inoki's query in Japan's parliament, the Diet, stating that the ASDF had never detected any UFOs from outer space. Nakatani explained that while the ASDF scrambles fighter jets to observe any unidentified flying objects that might violate Japan's airspace, they have only found birds or other non-aircraft objects. Inoki, known for his wrestling career and political endeavors, including a wrestling tournament in North Korea, also claims to have seen a UFO but does not personally confirm the existence of aliens. This exchange is part of a broader discussion in Japanese politics about the implications of extraterrestrial threats.

A passenger named Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after he broke a toilet he was standing on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China. Jin Pai had been standing on the rim of the toilet because he was concerned about its cleanliness. The toilet collapsed, causing him to fall and sustain severe injuries. He was found bleeding on the floor and had to call his traveling companions for help. He received numerous stitches in the hospital. Jin Pai initially told his friends he was squatting but later lied to the police, claiming he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities consider the incident an accident and reminded people that toilets are meant for sitting.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested on charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, which police traced back to Rebbie. The girl reported that Rebbie had sexually abused her from ages nine to 13 and filmed her and others using the bathroom, capturing 41 videos, 34 of which showed victims showering. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims and had purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created an intriguing series of father-daughter portraits where fathers leap into the air next to their daughters. In these images, the daughters maintain a serious expression while their fathers adopt dramatic, energetic poses, often looking slightly pained. The daughters typically wear casual clothing, while their fathers are dressed in sharp suits, possibly symbolizing the "salary man" concept. The photographs are set against various Japanese landmarks and are part of Aoyama's latest book, which roughly translates to "Daughter and Salaryman." Despite limited information about the series, the unique concept has garnered significant online interest.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the subsequent focus on the upcoming county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially dropped by Downton in 2014, is now with Surrey and appears reflective yet jovial as he poses for the team photo at the KIA Oval. Pietersen's return to Surrey is seen as a step towards potentially rejoining the England Test team. The passage highlights Pietersen's interactions with photographers and teammates, showing his efforts to regain his place in the England set-up as Surrey prepares for their campaign starting on April 19 against Glamorgan.

The relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 international caps, was initially fired after a poor run but was reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. However, he was let go again following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, which left Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, who replaced Florin Marin in January, will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes the Colombian striker regrets his failed loan move to Manchester United. Falcao, who moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan, struggled to perform at the same level he achieved before a serious knee injury. Despite scoring only four goals this season, Manchester United is unlikely to pay the £46 million to make the transfer permanent. Dirar suggests Falcao might have been better off staying at Monaco, where he was reportedly unhappy but could have participated in the Champions League.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a very tall man who robbed a dairy in Christchurch while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. The robber, captured on security footage, stole the dairy's till containing approximately $1,500 in cash on Saturday. The incident occurred at around 12:30 PM when the masked man demanded cash from the owner's daughter, causing her to flee the shop screaming. Although no weapons were seen, the robber remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice in March. Initially, she was arrested on March 19 for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail. Shortly after, another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January in her car near another school in Dallas. Granado was arrested again on Monday and released after posting a $50,000 bail. She is currently on administrative leave, unable to work with students or be present on school property. The Irving school district assured families that appropriate actions were taken.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog from a local bike shop owner in its jaws has garnered over 500,000 views online. The incident occurred while New Zealander Tim Weston was on holiday with his wife. The crocodile held onto the dog for hours, and although there is a sanctuary for crocodiles nearby, the dog had approached the water curiously. Social media reactions to the video have been largely horrified, with some users expressing fear towards crocodiles. Despite the shock, crocodiles are a common sight in Puerto Vallarta due to its mangrove environment.

Steve Bruce remains confident that Hull City can avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League despite a challenging season. After a 2-0 loss to Southampton, Hull City is just two points clear of the relegation zone with six games remaining. Initially aiming for 10 wins to survive, Bruce now believes that "nine or eight might be enough." Hull City faced tough fixtures against top teams like Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to several long-term injuries to key players, including Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Despite the difficulties, Bruce is convinced that a positive attitude will help Hull City secure the necessary results to stay in the Premier League. Meanwhile, Southampton's Ronald Koeman had to address a disciplinary issue involving Sadio Mane attempting to take a penalty instead of James Ward-Prowse.

A teacher named Ian Guffick was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their SATs exam answers, invalidating the entire school's results for Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. Despite the exam session ending, Guffick asked students to modify their answers and also altered some himself before submitting the papers. An investigation by the local education authority confirmed these breaches of exam rules, leading the Department for Education to annul all SATs results for the school. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted his actions constituted unacceptable professional conduct. Although he claimed he only wanted to make the answers more legible, the conduct panel emphasized that no changes should be made outside test conditions. The panel acknowledged Guffick's remorse but deemed his actions deliberate and serious enough to warrant the classroom ban.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United's goalkeeper, has had limited playing time but enjoys a happy personal life with his wife, Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model of Albanian descent. The couple married in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year and have a son together. Lindegaard shared a picture with Beqiri on his Instagram, highlighting their relationship. Despite his struggles for regular appearances at Manchester United, Lindegaard remains popular off the pitch, while Beqiri frequently posts modeling photos on her Instagram, which has over 17,000 followers. Lindegaard has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is currently third-choice goalkeeper at Old Trafford.

The iconic glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium in the Bronx failed to attract any buyers at a Sotheby's auction. Expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000, the only bid made was by a Sotheby's employee for $260,000 to initiate the bidding. The current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, bought the 10-feet-tall letters after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson, who attended the auction, had hoped to see a new generation enjoy this symbol of the Yankees and New York City. Despite Jackson's promise to visit the new owner if the letters were bought by a U.S. bidder, they remained unsold. Additionally, Sotheby's auctioned a New York Mets bullpen car, which fetched a winning bid of $112,500 despite its lower estimated value.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed the professional conduct of players Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe after a week that saw them exposed for using nitrous oxide and being photographed with shisha pipes. Despite these incidents, Rodgers has chosen not to discipline either player and instead emphasized the importance of their responsibilities as elite sportspersons. Rodgers' main focus remains on steering Liverpool into their first FA Cup final under his tenure, with captain Steven Gerrard available after a suspension. Rodgers highlighted the importance of learning from near misses in sports to drive improvement.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, appeared to be enjoying his time in London after returning from the international break, sharing a picture of himself relaxing with his dog. Ozil played a key role in Germany's 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2020 qualifier. Despite missing Arsenal's recent game against Newcastle due to illness, he is expected to start in the upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. Ozil has been performing well since his return from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January. He also shared his adaptation to English football, noting that he fits in "perfectly" due to the frequent match schedule.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that there are no plans to replace Luis Enrique, emphasizing that the club is "very happy" with him. Enrique, who took charge last summer and signed a two-year deal, is six games away from winning the La Liga title. Despite speculation about his replacement, Bartomeu refuted these claims and expressed his satisfaction with Enrique's performance. The president highlighted Enrique's hard work and dedication, noting that Barcelona is still in contention to win three trophies this season. In a recent match, Barcelona defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay at Anfield until the summer of 2020. The new deal, worth around £100,000 per week, comes after the club's FA Cup disappointment. Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has been one of the standout performers this season, contributing 13 assists and seven goals. He is set to potentially replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy. This contract extension follows similar deals for Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Talks regarding Raheem Sterling's future are expected to resume after the season, though Sterling has already rejected a new deal.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. He signed a three-year deal when he moved from Atletico last July but has had difficulty securing the left-back position at Stamford Bridge. Luis emphasized his happiness at Chelsea and his commitment to fulfilling his contract. He recently played for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile and now focuses on Chelsea's Premier League campaign, where manager Jose Mourinho insists on maintaining focus and winning every game. Luis acknowledges the difficulty of the remaining nine games but believes the team is prepared to handle the challenge.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after accidentally knocking out George North during a Northampton try on March 27. Initially, Hughes was deemed "reckless" and received a red card, but the ban was rescinded following an appeal and public outcry. The appeal panel concluded that the incident was accidental and no foul play occurred. Hughes, who missed a Champions Cup match due to the suspension, is now free to play but is not in the squad for Wasps' upcoming match, suggesting he may return on April 26 against Exeter.

The passage describes how a fiery sunset in Washington, captured by Seattle native Tim Durkan, was caused by wildfires in Siberia. These fires, initially started by farmers burning grass, grew out of control due to strong winds on April 14, spreading across the region and destroying many villages. The smoke from these fires was carried by winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense reddish color of the sunsets is due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange to dominate. This effect is more pronounced during sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the reddish hue of the sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was later found by police after a man recognized it and returned it with new red rims and detailing. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook, noting that her car now looked "pimped out." She plans to professionally clean the car to remove the smell of cigarettes and marijuana and is creating a smoothie called the Sexton on Wheels at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who found her car.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they do not qualify for the Champions League this season. The Premier League title holders offer star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure incentivised contracts to comply with financial fairplay rules. City are currently in fourth place, just four points ahead of Liverpool, and face a crucial battle to secure a top-four finish. The top three teams automatically qualify for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. In total, the City squad has around £12 million in bonuses at stake. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team's poor performance in recent months, which has jeopardized their European hopes. If City fail to qualify, they will miss out on significant bonuses and face challenges in signing top players like Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba.

In a "mini-derby" match, Manchester United's Under 18s defeated City 1-0. The match featured 13 English players, 10 of whom were from Manchester. Callum Gribbin scored the decisive goal with a free-kick. The game was held at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with free entry and around 1,000 spectators. United's coach, Paul McGuinness, aimed to simulate senior team conditions for his players, who used a three-at-the-back formation. Despite chances for both sides, including a near-goal from City's Marcus Wood and missed opportunities by Marcus Rashford, Gribbin's free-kick secured the win for United. City's Javairo Dilrosun scored a late free-kick, but it wasn't enough. United now leads the Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-off series, two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has lost both matches in the series.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised fellow goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who celebrated his 50th cap for England on the same night, expressed admiration for Buffon's continued excellence at 37 years old and his own aspirations to learn from Buffon. Hart also expressed pride in his own milestone and a desire to continue accumulating caps for both his club, Manchester City, and his country, England.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to enter the $70 billion food delivery market, offering delivery services for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. The service will include a nine percent service charge, with delivery fees starting at $5 and varying based on distance and demand. This move comes after Chipotle reportedly declined previous delivery service collaborations. The fast-casual chain has seen growth, with notable customers including presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton. Other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or already offering delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have made a heartfelt plea to remove the death penalty from consideration for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the bombings. In a front-page opinion piece in The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard detailed the profound impact the tragedy has had on their family, including the death of their 8-year-old son and severe injuries to their daughter. They argue that pursuing the death penalty would only lead to years of appeals and further anguish for their family. Instead, they support Tsarnaev spending the rest of his life in prison without the possibility of release and waiving all rights to appeal. They emphasize that their plea is personal and they hope it will help bring closure and a better future for their family, Boston, and the country.

The passage describes an extravagant Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet that has been transformed into a luxury home for a wealthy billionaire, costing an estimated £400 million. This custom-built aircraft, originally designed to carry up to 600 passengers, has been reconfigured to cater to the exclusive needs of its single owner, though it can accommodate numerous guests. The plane features multiple lounges, bedrooms, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a conference room, and a state room. The top deck includes an 'aeroloft' with eight beds. The interior boasts a hotel-like ambiance, complete with luxurious decor and amenities, making it one of the most opulent private planes ever constructed.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket with an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to deliver supplies to the International Space Station. Although the rocket successfully delivered Dragon to its destination, SpaceX failed to land the rocket's first stage on a drone ship at sea, as it tipped over. Elon Musk stated that the rocket stage landed but was too damaged to survive. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS and the second attempt after a weather-related delay. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies and return with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and waste. SpaceX aims to reuse rockets to reduce space travel costs.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding held at a new chapel of love in Las Vegas, collaborating with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the "ultimate wedding." The winning couple, announced next Monday, will marry at Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel on April 23. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla Presley emphasized that no impersonators are allowed and that the chapel is a serious, first-class affair. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside his Memphis home, and couples must submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve the prize to be the first to wed there.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after overcoming a challenging season. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season in Liverpool's 2-0 win over Newcastle United, tying a record for appearances in the top five European leagues this campaign. Henderson thinks Liverpool can pressure City, who are four points ahead, after regaining winning form. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring with skill, and Joe Allen capitalized on a defensive error for his first Anfield goal. Despite a potential penalty claim by Newcastle, Liverpool secured a crucial victory.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the decisive goal in the 25th minute from a swift counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis was instrumental in preserving the lead by making several key saves in the second half. The victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio. Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, and they remained in fifth place. Security was tight for the match, with no reported issues. Roma was without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, but Pjanic made an immediate impact. The match saw several key saves from de Sanctis, including a leaping save in the 64th minute. Napoli's Lorenzo Insigne made his first appearance since a knee injury.

The passage describes Doncaster Rovers' uninspired performance in League One, which has left them in mid-table mediocrity. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town ended in a goalless draw, which was so uneventful that the club's media team struggled to compile match highlights. They opted to make a very short highlight video, just 27 seconds long, featuring only 14 seconds of actual match action, including the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

The passage describes a unique bond between a man named Roland Giroux and his blood parrot cichlid. Unlike typical marine pets, this fish has developed a sociable relationship with Giroux, allowing him to gently stroke and massage it within its tank. Initially, the fish was bullied by other tank mates, but after they were removed, Giroux began feeding the fish by hand and interacting with it daily. Over time, the fish became accustomed to and enjoyed Giroux's touch, often returning to be stroked. The fish even swims up Giroux's arm and interacts with his fingers. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid bred in Taiwan in 1986, shows clear signs of distress when Giroux removes his hand, indicating its attachment to the daily interactions.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' fiery character and his return to the England cricket team. It highlights the intense and unforgiving environment of the dressing room, where nothing is sacred. Stokes is remembered for breaking his wrist punching a locker in frustration, serving as a reminder to channel his aggression constructively. Despite a clash with Marlon Samuels, Stokes responded positively after a conversation with coach Peter Moores, showing his natural exuberance and desire to challenge opponents. The passage emphasizes the need for careful management to control Stokes' aggression while still allowing his natural fiery character to contribute to the team's success. England aims to maximize Stokes' potential and includes him along with Chris Jordan, despite the occasional need to manage their roles, especially with only rare opportunities for two spinners. The overall tone is optimistic about Stokes' growth and contribution to the team.

The Euro 2016 qualifier between Wales and Belgium, scheduled for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are tied with 11 points each from five games in Group B, but Belgium leads due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel, led by Gareth Bale's brilliant free-kick, has boosted hopes of qualifying for the tournament. The Football Association of Wales reported high ticket demand, leading to a sell-out. Despite speculation, the match will be held at the Cardiff City Stadium instead of the Millennium Stadium due to UEFA regulations and the team's preference for the more intimate venue.

England coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The team, known as the Young Lions, are the defending champions and have qualified with a perfect record in the qualifiers. They are grouped with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland in Group D, with their first match against Italy on May 7 in Burgas. The squad includes promising young players from various Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, who is making his first call-up. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have been recalled after missing the previous qualifiers. The team's other matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht talent Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best young players from Anderlecht's youth system. Patoulidis has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Despite Barcelona's offer, he declined to join their academy at age 12 to focus on his studies. Manchester City has engaged in talks with Anderlecht's chairman, Roger Vanden Stock, to negotiate a compensation package. Manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to build the team's future by acquiring Patoulidis.

A 33-year-old transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed pending further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Vanessa Santillan, who moved to London from Mexico, worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, according to her website. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and emphasized the need for information from anyone who knew her in London.

Dawn, a woman who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show to address the theft of £207 that she had saved for a gravestone for one of her babies, Daniel James. She accused her housemate and long-term friend, Jamie, of stealing the money. Despite Jamie's initial denial, a lie detector test conducted by Jeremy Kyle confirmed Jamie's guilt. Jamie, who has a history of burglary, also sent a Facebook message confessing to the theft but blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn expressed her deep distress and betrayal, especially poignant given her history of miscarriages. The revelation led to an emotional confrontation on the show, with Dawn bursting into tears and storming off the stage.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group in northern Iraq, who had been killed, captured, or displaced when ISIS overtook their towns last summer. Most of those released were women and children, with the remainder being ill or elderly. The release was coordinated with the help of Arab tribal leaders, though the exact motivation remains unclear. The freed Yazidis were transported to Irbil by the Peshmerga force. This release follows previous instances where ISIS freed scores of Yazidis, primarily children and the elderly. The Yazidis, of Kurdish descent and followers of a pre-Islamic religion, have faced severe persecution, including mass killings, rape, and enslavement by ISIS. The group's plight led to international intervention, including airstrikes against ISIS and humanitarian aid airdrops.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Harry Kane, Tottenham's young striker, has had an incredible season marked by animated celebrations both on and off the pitch. He is nominated for the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation by Copa90 showcases Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', features his notable goals against Chelsea and Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. The video is released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers remains the right man to lead Liverpool despite a trophyless season and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, speaking after receiving a Beacon Award for his community work, emphasized that Rodgers' future shouldn't be judged on one season and highlighted the challenges of integrating new players. Liverpool is currently seven points behind the fourth-placed team with a game in hand, likely missing out on Champions League qualification. Carragher expressed optimism for next season, stressing the importance of right signings for improvement. Additionally, Carragher received the Beacon Award for his community work through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in schools in deprived areas of Merseyside.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was deemed a security risk by airport staff, leading to a thorough frisk and inspection of the child. James's father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security staff for being "over-zealous" and described the checks as "ludicrous." The airport apologized for the inconvenience and offered to return the toy, but the family chose to buy a replacement upon their return from a holiday in Lanzarote. The airport defended its actions, citing government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited items through security.

A lonely man from Humpty Doo in the Northern Territory has posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The ad, from a man who identifies only as Rich, lists numerous requirements for his ideal partner, including being fit, attractive, non-drinker, non-smoker, reliable, honest, loyal, good in the kitchen, and good in bed. Rich also specified that his ideal partner should enjoy the outdoors but also be comfortable being pampered. Rich, who is 31 years old, described himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, and successful, emphasizing his love for travel, the outdoors, sports, and his independence. He promised significant benefits to the successful candidate, including a company car, phone, and laptop, and assured that all reasonable offers would be considered, though former partners need not apply. Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact Rich for further details.

The Football Association chairman, Greg Dyke, has received support from five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—for his plan to implement radical changes in football. Dyke aims to raise the minimum number of home-grown players in Premier League squads from eight to 12 and redefine "home-grown" to mean training in England for three years before the age of 18 instead of 21. The former managers warn that blocking these proposals could harm the English game and hinder England's chances of winning major tournaments, noting that only 36.8% of recent Premier League starters were eligible for England selection. They emphasize the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level and highlight emerging young talents like Harry Kane, Raheem Sterling, and Ross Barkley, stressing the need for more opportunities for homegrown players.

The passage discusses the latest developments in the TV show "Poldark," focusing on the character Demelza Poldark, who has become a proud mother. The show's viewers are excited to see Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, lovingly gazing at his newborn daughter in the upcoming episode. Despite the public's romantic interest in Ross, it's noted that his heart is taken. The passage also highlights the unrealistic pace of Demelza's pregnancy, which jumps from the announcement to full term and childbirth within a short span of time, a trend that has drawn commentary from fans on social media.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to stay focused and ignore their relegation rivals as they prepare to host Swansea City. Despite being bottom of the Barclays Premier League table, the Foxes have won their last two matches, including a crucial 3-2 victory over West Bromwich Albion, with Jamie Vardy scoring the winning goal in injury time. Pearson emphasized that their future depends on their own performance and urged his players to concentrate on their remaining games rather than the standings of other teams. He cautioned against becoming overly optimistic due to recent results.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers) from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey, tracked by scientists from Oregon State University, surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales during her migration, suggesting she might actually be an eastern gray whale rather than the endangered western gray whale species. This discovery could indicate a need for further genetic studies to differentiate between the species, especially given the critically low population of western gray whales, estimated at only 150.

Residents on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island experienced an unexpected change of scenery overnight as 1,000ft of seabed on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu was forced to the surface, rising up to 50ft above sea level. The new stretch of land, measuring roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, emerged without warning and no local tremors or sounds were reported. Geologists attribute the phenomenon to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow. Authorities believe the land movement is not related to recent earthquakes elsewhere and do not expect further expansion. Marine organisms remain attached to the newly exposed seabed.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer, expressing his love for the club. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea, Van der Wiel insists he is content at PSG and has no plans to leave. He stated his happiness at PSG, his affection for the city and teammates, and his desire to sign a new contract. PSG is also reportedly interested in signing Barcelona's Dani Alves, which could affect Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to terminate his contract with Juventus to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite his contract with Juventus running until the end of the next season, Tevez reportedly wants to leave this summer. Boca Juniors has confirmed they are close to finalizing a deal for the 31-year-old striker, but club president Daniel Angelici emphasized that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Tevez, who joined Juventus and has been their top scorer this season with 17 goals, has always intended to finish his career at Boca Juniors. Juventus, though reluctant to lose their top scorer, have accepted Tevez's decision and are identifying potential replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that a move to Boca Juniors would not affect Tevez's future with the Argentina national team.

In a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich triumphed over Porto with a 6-1 victory, booking their place in the semi-finals. The game was marked by an amusing incident involving Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola, who tore the left leg of his trousers, exposing his underwear. Guardiola joked about needing to buy new trousers for the next match. The goals were scored by Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Despite Porto's 3-1 lead from the first leg in Portugal, Bayern's dominant performance left them stunned.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale in Brisbane's west. Three vehicles collided, resulting in several injuries. Four individuals, including a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries, a five-year-old boy with chest pain, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries, and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain, were airlifted to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or further assessment. A man suffered hand lacerations, and two females escaped injuries. The highway was closed with diversions in place, and emergency crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free a trapped individual.

This weekend, Premier League's second-placed Arsenal will host league leaders Chelsea. Arsenal's star player Mesut Ozil recently received a new Apple Watch, which he showcased on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from the show Knight Rider. Ozil is expected to play in the upcoming match against Chelsea. Arsenal is currently 10 points behind Chelsea with six games left. The team has been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench in the FA Cup semi-final win over Reading. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere is the future of the club if he can stay fit, citing his impressive skills but noting his history of injuries.

Referee Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford on Sunday. Despite past accusations of favoring United, Clattenburg has sent off only two players this season in the Premier League, both of whom were from Manchester United: Tyler Blackett in a 5-3 defeat by Leicester and Luke Shaw in a 1-1 draw with West Ham. Notably, Clattenburg sent off Manchester City captain Vincent Kompany during an international match, resulting in his suspension for the upcoming match against Wales. The upcoming derby is highly significant as it could determine the second-place finish in the league, with United currently leading City by one point. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of assuming embattled MP Billy Gordon would resign after accusations of domestic violence and hiding a criminal past. Katter made a controversial statement on his party's website, suggesting the government viewed Gordon as "a little black puppet on a string." This sparked criticism on social media. Katter defended his terminology, citing his personal experiences with racism and emphasizing the racial overtones of his statement. Despite the controversy, Gordon announced he would remain in the Queensland parliament as an independent, causing potential chaos for the government with its slim majority. Katter compared Gordon's situation to federal MPs who lost their independence, vowing Gordon would not make the same mistake.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using dance to inspire and challenge stereotypes. Despite facing bullying and negative perceptions due to her disability, she creates enthusiastic dance videos to counteract these stereotypes and encourage others to think before judging. Dayna aims to show that people with disabilities can lead normal, active lives and participate fully in society. She has produced multiple dance videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and has started motivational speaking at local schools to further her mission.

Orlando City, an MLS side, has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. The Florida-based team, coached by Adrian Heath, has a significant Latin-American fanbase and believes Hernandez would be a commercial draw. However, Hernandez is also attracting interest from eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to their 19-year-old prospect, Andreas Pereira, who has also caught the attention of several European clubs like Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A group of at least three people attempted to carjack a man at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday. After an argument, they poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers were inside. Fortunately, no one was injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

A chiropractor in southern Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic released a report detailing these charges. Manuel admitted his misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these serious allegations, he has received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com, with a perfect five out of five stars based on just three survey responses. Manuel's practice was located in Lamoni, a small agricultural town in southern Iowa.

A U.S. reconnaissance plane, an RC-135U, was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. Pentagon described the Russian pilot's actions as "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers and high speed. The Russian Defense Ministry claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off, which the U.S. denied. The U.S. will file a complaint through diplomatic channels. This follows a similar incident a year ago where a Russian jet came within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, prompting a Pentagon complaint. Encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are common in Northern Europe and the area between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was forcibly taken by breaking the rear right passenger-side window and using another vehicle's momentum to rip the case free. The theft occurred just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, but it has not been recovered. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras. The Secret Service was notified before Obama's visit, but it's unclear if this theft influenced security measures.

In 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in the dining room of his home in Red Hill, Canberra. The jury heard that Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa post-incident and concluded that Costa's state of mind was declining due to dementia and alcohol abuse, which contributed to his confused mental state during the attack. Mullen testified that Costa's fluctuating mood and a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet indicated his compromised mental state. The prosecutor suggested Costa feigned memory issues, but Mullen denied these claims. Costa's mental state is crucial to the case, as a proven unstable mindset at the time of the attack could lead to a not guilty verdict.

In a 1-0 win against Burnley at Goodison Park, Everton manager Roberto Martinez had to address another missed penalty by the team. Ross Barkley, instead of Leighton Baines who has a successful penalty record, inexplicably took the 10th-minute penalty awarded for a foul on Aaron Lennon. Despite the save by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, Everton secured the victory with a goal by Kevin Mirallas after 29 minutes. Martinez defended Barkley's choice to take the penalty, emphasizing the importance of having multiple penalty takers based on their confidence. This incident recalled a similar situation in January when Kevin Mirallas missed a penalty against West Brom after taking it instead of Baines.

Two passengers on the cruise ship ms Ryndam operated by Holland America Line were found dead in their stateroom in Puerto Rico, and the cruise line indicated it appears to be a murder-suicide. The incident occurred on Thursday at 11:30 a.m. The cabin was secured immediately, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. The ship departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The deceased were discovered by cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin door. The investigation is ongoing, and the authorities will determine the official cause.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully guided Curacao to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced with a 4-3 aggregate win after a 2-2 draw in Montserrat, with a 2-1 victory in Willemstad. Kluivert's team secured a crucial goal in the 87th minute through Charlton Vicento. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round, scheduled for June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, has a history of involvement in World Cup campaigns, including a semi-final finish in 1998 as a player and as an assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, who has won numerous major European competitions throughout his career, considers helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League to be one of his greatest achievements. Despite the Foxes being at the bottom of the table with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic and equates the task to winning a trophy. He signed a one-year deal with Leicester in the summer after a decade at Inter Milan, where he won 15 trophies. Cambiasso is determined to help Leicester stay in the Premier League and is happy in his current situation, hinting at a possible extension beyond his current contract.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma, who has two young children by different fathers, is at risk of being banned from seeing her kids by her own mother, Debbie. Debbie, who has been caring for the children since they were four months old after social services threatened to take them away, believes Gemma is unfit to have custody due to her excessive drinking, partying, and alleged drug use. Debbie also suspects Gemma of stealing an iPad and other items to fund her lifestyle. Despite Gemma's claims that she did not steal the iPad, she admits to stealing money and items from Debbie in the past. Debbie, who has raised the children alone, is now determined to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children because she cannot trust her not to steal from them. Debbie emphasizes that Gemma prioritizes drinking and partying over her children and motherhood.

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored the opening goal. During the build-up, Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, causing Falcao to fall. The loose ball was then picked up by Cesc Fabregas, leading to Hazard's goal. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness believed that play should have been stopped for Terry's foul on Falcao. Souness pointed out that Terry's elbow in Falcao's head constituted a foul, while Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao and Redknapp acknowledged that while Falcao could have stayed on his feet better, Terry's challenge was still a foul.

The tour bus of Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott caught fire on Interstate 30 in Texas, but everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated. Michael Barnett filmed the dramatic scene and uploaded it to CNN iReport. The fire started after a rear tire blew out. Scott expressed gratitude for everyone's safety on Instagram and noted that the fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except her Bible. The band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus at the time. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

The passage discusses the potential of space lasers to provide future energy solutions, as proposed by Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University. Dr. Quarterman's idea involves satellites equipped with mirrors to capture sunlight and convert it into laser beams that can be directed back to Earth to power solar panels and potentially heat homes. This technology could make solar power viable in regions like Scotland and restore power quickly in disaster areas. Unlike sci-fi portrayals, these lasers won't be powerful enough to cause harm, such as blinding a pigeon or destroying planets. Additionally, the passage mentions a separate concept by Tokyo researchers to use lasers on the International Space Station to clear space debris, which also won't be powerful enough to function as a weapon. However, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges concerns about who controls such satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old predatory convicted paedophile with a fanatical obsession for young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who stands about 5ft 8ins tall and has a heavy build with dark hair, was last seen leaving the hospital on Tuesday at 6.15pm. He was detained under the Mental Health Act after being convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus in full view of her family. Munden also admitted to possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. Officers believe he may have shaved off his beard before leaving the hospital. A manhunt has been launched, and authorities urge anyone with information on his whereabouts to come forward urgently.

V. Stiviano is the former female companion of Donald Sterling, who was banned from the NBA and fined heavily after making racist remarks. She received over $2.6 million in lavish gifts from Sterling, including luxury cars and expensive items. A Los Angeles judge has ordered Stiviano to repay these gifts after Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, sued her, claiming Stiviano targeted wealthy older men. Shelly Sterling's lawyer described the court decision as a victory for the Sterling family and a precedent for injured spouses to recover ill-gotten gifts.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer activities and suggested they need to sign four key players to have a chance at winning the Premier League title. He specifically mentioned the need for a goalkeeper, a centre back, a defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker. Henry also questioned whether Arsenal can win the league with Olivier Giroud as their main striker, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. He cited Chelsea's successful signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as examples of the kind of reinforcements Arsenal need. Henry made these comments after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea and as a Sky Sports pundit.

A young woman testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who cannot be named, expressed fear for her future relationships and confusion about why she was targeted. She revealed that she had attempted to take her own life and has suffered from depression since she was 14. Van Ryn sat calmly in the dock without looking at her as she recounted the trauma. The court hearing continues, and support for suicide prevention is available through Lifeline on 13 11 14.

Serge Gnabry, the 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering well from a serious knee injury that has sidelined him for over a year. He last played for the first team in March 2014. Gnabry recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s in a match against Reading, marking his return to the field. He expressed optimism about his recovery, stating he is feeling "better and better" and is looking forward to future games.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, tragically died after falling down a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales. Phillips and his friends had taken a taxi home after a night out in Cardiff but didn't have enough cash to pay the fare. They decided to run from the taxi driver in the dark, with Phillips leaping over a fence and falling down the cliff. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, stopped because he couldn't see in the dark and was unaware of the danger Phillips faced. Phillips' body was found the next day on the rocky beach by a dog walker. The coroner concluded that Phillips' death was accidental, noting that he likely became disoriented and didn't realize the danger of the cliff nearby. Phillips worked for Pretty Green, a clothing label owned by Liam Gallagher, and had been studying accountancy at the University of Birmingham.

The passage highlights the aftermath of last summer's passport delay fiasco, where thousands of holidaymakers did not receive compensation despite having to pay extra fees for expedited services. The HM Passport Office made a £42 million profit during this period, and managers received bonuses up to £3,500. Ministers refused to provide blanket refunds, citing the creation of a precedent. Only 2,191 out of many thousands of affected holidaymakers received compensation, totaling £203,066, with an average payout of £92.68. Keith Vaz, chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, expressed astonishment at the low number of approved compensation claims given the office's substantial profit. Despite numerous complaints, only one of the contacted holidaymakers received any refund.

The passage describes a timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, that has remained largely unchanged since the 1930s, complete with original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and vintage cupboards. The semi-detached property, valued between £200,000 and £250,000, includes an original bathroom with mint green and black tiles, a wood-panelled hallway lit by stained-glass windows depicting ships, and a kitchen with original 1930s cupboards and a brick open-face fire. The house also features quirky original tins of produce from the past. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, the potential renovation costs might deter developers, making it an ideal family home for antique enthusiasts. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith. After Smith suffered a concussion mid-2012, Kaepernick became the 49ers' starting quarterback for the remainder of the season. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.

The passage provides information about the 1997 American comedy-drama film "Soul Food." It was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and it was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, moved to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45 mi freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network that is owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, specifically NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed the band Blur. Blur's debut album "Leisure" was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. The band later achieved worldwide success with their self-titled album in 2001. Albarn's debut solo album "Everyday Robots," co-produced by Richard Russell, was released on April 28, 2014, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, along with samples from Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It hosts many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP) titled Broken, which was released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage provides information about two adaptations featuring Bob Lee Swagger. In the 2007 film "Shooter," Mark Wahlberg portrays Swagger, a Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue private military company. In the TV series "Shooter," Ryan Phillippe stars as Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action upon discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American medical drama television series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, starting on November 16, 2004, and ending on May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate.
