David Spade is an actor who has starred and co-starred in several films, including "Tommy Boy," "Black Sheep," "Joe Dirt," "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser," "Grown Ups," and "Grown Ups 2." "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser" is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

The album Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the United States Billboard 200 with 258,000 copies sold in its first week. It became Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the U.S. and sold 757,000 copies. Globally, it was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies sold.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, titled "Stadium Arcadium." This album marked the last with guitarist John Frusciante, who left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She remains a controversial figure, celebrated as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, despite ongoing debates about her policies.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Besides his musical career, he has written weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series in addition to his acting roles.

Valencia, officially known as València, is the capital of the Valencian Community, an autonomous community in Spain. It is the third largest city in Spain, following Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative center. Valencia also constitutes the third largest metropolitan area in Spain, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million.
The passage provides information about the character Buffy Summers, noting that she was initially portrayed by Kristy Swanson in a film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The passage states that on April 26, 2012, it was announced that the series "Make It or Break It" would end with its third season, which aired its finale on May 14, 2012.

The passage provides a summary of speech recognition (SR), highlighting it as an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that translates spoken language into text using methodologies from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. SR applications include voice user interfaces for tasks like voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft voice commands. The field has seen significant academic and industry advancements, particularly through the adoption of deep learning methods by major companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf, born on January 26, 1952, and passed away on January 4, 2012, was an American businessman and comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, initially named the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970, alongside Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. Alf served as the chairman of the convention starting from its inception.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally featured Bruce Lee as the lead character.

In summary, France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied at 16 under par after Dubuisson shot a 67. Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy shot his third consecutive five-under-par 67 to reach 15 under par, alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy's round included an eagle on the 12th hole as he aims for his first title win since May. Despite some early mistakes, McIlroy recovered with birdies and an eagle. He is also targeting a third Race to Dubai title, leading England's Danny Willett by a significant margin with three events left. Meanwhile, English players Chris Wood and Richard Bland, who were tied for second overnight, are now in fifth and seventh place respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the necessity for the Bahraini government to demonstrate a genuine commitment to offering "concrete solutions" for a meaningful national dialogue. He highlighted the importance of engaging reformists within the royal family, particularly Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who is seen as a proponent of accommodating the Shia majority. Despite opposition from hardliners, including the unelected Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, Sheikh Salman insisted on the necessity of dialogue and negotiations. He expressed hope in the new US Secretary of State, John Kerry, to push harder for human rights and democratic practices in Bahrain. On the UK's role, he criticized the lack of public pressure and urged the government to speak out against violence and human rights abuses. Sheikh Salman reiterated al-Wefaq's stance on peaceful demonstrations and called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and activists imprisoned on controversial charges.

The passage provides a concise summary of the life and career of conductor Christopher Hogwood, who passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood was a pivotal figure in the early-music movement, founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he directed for 30 years and which produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Notable among his recordings is the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, which was highly acclaimed. Hogwood's academic and professional affiliations included roles at Harvard University, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell University, as well as artistic directorships at the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. Colleagues and friends remember him as an extraordinary, generous, and influential figure in historically informed music.

In the year to the end of March, there were 57 recorded homicides in Scotland, marking a decrease of five cases compared to the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. A sharp instrument, particularly a knife, was the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides. While most accused had an unknown status for alcohol and drugs, 31% were identified as being under the influence. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts to reduce violent crime, highlighting the role of public services and law enforcement. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker welcomed the decrease in homicides but cautioned against over-optimism due to increases in sexual crime and violent crime. The original figure for homicides in the previous year was 59 but was later revised to 62.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland on Saturday, marking the first Premier League defeat for Sunderland this season. Sunderland's goals came from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Bournemouth's Dan Gosling had earlier scored their first goal in three games. Despite creating numerous chances, Bournemouth couldn't find an equalizer, especially after Steven Pienaar was sent off. Manager Howe emphasized that the team's performance wasn't due to a lack of confidence, pointing out they had scored six goals against Hull before these games. Howe concluded by noting that while they had enough chances to win, sometimes football doesn't pan out that way, and it's about how the team moves forward from such results.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Mr. Abbott, an Australian leader, emphasized that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," referring to migrants attempting to reach Australia by boat. Australia detains these migrants and processes them in offshore camps. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and "of dubious legality," and warned European leaders against adopting similar policies. Abbott defended his stance by referencing the tragic image of Syrian boy Alan Kurdi, who drowned while trying to reach Greece. Additionally, Abbott angered some Australian Jewish groups by comparing the Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, a comment that was deemed inappropriate by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry. Despite criticism, Abbott stood by his remarks.

The passage highlights the deteriorating situation in Aleppo, Syria, where intensified attacks by Russia and the Syrian government against civilians have led to significant casualties, including children. The US has suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia aimed at sustaining the cessation of hostilities, accusing Russia and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's forces of failing to adhere to agreements and targeting critical infrastructure like hospitals. The US also cites the attack on a humanitarian aid convoy as evidence of this failure. In response, Russia expresses regret over the US decision and accuses Washington of not fulfilling its part of the agreement, particularly in improving the humanitarian situation in Aleppo and distinguishing between jihadist groups and moderate opposition. Despite the suspension of talks, both sides agree to continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations to prevent clashes.

The passage discusses a report by think tank Policy Exchange suggesting that selling high-value vacant social homes could raise £4.5bn annually, enough to build between 80,000 and 170,000 new social homes. The report argues this could kickstart the economy and reduce the number of people waiting for social housing by about 500,000. However, Labour opposes this, arguing it would displace low-income families and worsen the housing crisis. The government supports the idea, suggesting councils should use their social housing stock more efficiently. Critics, including Labour and the National Housing Federation, argue this would create segregated communities and "cleanse" towns of hard-working people. The government counters that it has introduced reforms to increase affordable housing and reduce waiting lists.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, a city experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 cases. The cause of his death remains uncertain as tests could not confirm if measles was the primary cause. An inquest will be held and adjourned for further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment for the illness. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma at Swansea's Morriston Hospital and developed a rash days before his death. Public Health Wales confirmed measles diagnosis through laboratory tests but further investigation is needed to determine the cause of death. The family is puzzled about how he contracted the disease as no close family member, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, has it.

Vincent Hudson, 54, from Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under the age of 16. The alleged attack reportedly occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear in North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

The passage describes a National League match between Gateshead and Guiseley, which ended in a 1-1 draw. Guiseley took an early lead in the 15th minute when Jake Lawlor scored from a throw-in. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute when Wes York capitalized on a slip by Gateshead's half-time substitute Derek Asamoah. The match saw several substitutions and yellow cards, with Gateshead's Gus Mafuta and Guiseley's Simon Walton receiving cautions. The match report was supplied by the Press Association.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase the stadium's capacity. This initiative is an alternative to a delayed new stadium proposal at Ashton Vale, which has been hindered by a town green application. The majority shareholder, Steve Lansdown, confirmed that the club will start the work at a shareholder meeting on Tuesday. The project was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Lansdown mentioned that the club will soon sign the section 106 agreement and anticipates a six-week wait for a judicial review. If no review is filed by March, the redevelopment plans will commence in May.

Cuadrilla, the company conducting shale gas drilling (fracking) in Lancashire, has suspended operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor occurred near their drilling site in Poulton-le-Fylde. This is the second tremor in two months, with the first occurring on April 1. The British Geological Survey (BGS) noted that both tremors share a similar location and mechanism. Cuadrilla will analyze the data collected by the BGS before deciding whether to resume operations, a process expected to take several weeks. The BGS is also monitoring the situation as a precaution. The BGS explained that injecting pressurized water during fracking can cause earthquakes. The latest tremor was felt by at least one person and occurred 1.2 miles from the drilling site at a depth of approximately 2km. The recorded waveforms suggest a similar mechanism to the previous tremor.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old piper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud after using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes to collect cash in April 2015. He denied three fraud charges, and was cleared of the other two counts by a jury at Liverpool Crown Court. Sgt Chris Gaynor testified that Carpenter gave the impression he was raising funds for the Hillsborough Justice Campaign. In his defense, Carpenter stated he had previously piped for the charity but was merely busking on this occasion. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, confirmed he had allowed Carpenter to design the banner but explicitly stated it should not be used for fundraising. Carpenter maintained the banner was a tribute to the victims, not a deceptive act. He is known for his regular performances on match days at Anfield and will be sentenced in January.

In a decisive match, Ipswich Town secured a 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers (QPR). Grant Ward opened the scoring with a scuffed shot, followed by Luke Varney capitalizing on a miscued clearance by QPR keeper Alex Smithies to roll the ball into an empty net. Tom Lawrence then finished a long-range shot from Cole Skuse to seal the win. QPR struggled offensively and had few chances, with Sandro hitting the post late in the game. Ipswich, who had struggled to score in recent matches, moved up to 14th place, while QPR slipped to 15th. Both managers expressed disappointment, with Ipswich's Mick McCarthy highlighting the irony of Smithies' costly error and QPR's Ian Holloway emphasizing the need for mental toughness among his players.

The passage highlights that Wells, a 23-year-old player, had a successful T20 Blast season last year, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. Wells expressed enthusiasm about the club's direction, noting the elite performance environment created by the coaches that motivates the players.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Coach Churcher praised players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams for their leadership and the team's strong performance, particularly noting the front row and front five making over 70 tackles. The Reds will face seven teams below them in the next eight games, including league leaders Old Elthamians. Despite the win, Churcher believes there is still room for improvement and emphasized the need to build on their recent success to avoid wasting their efforts.

The police have arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, on allegations that he raped a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town. Nazrul, a Bangladeshi citizen, was apprehended at a railway station in Kolkata after fleeing to Bangladesh. This arrest marks the sixth in connection to the crime, with police having identified eight suspects, two of whom remain untraced. The five previously arrested suspects have implicated Nazrul in the attack. The incident, which also involved the theft of money and ransacking of a convent school, has sparked outrage and protests across India.

The passage informs users that the interactive video may not work on older browsers and provides a non-interactive version. The video features Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, discussing factors influencing consumer buying habits in the UK, such as the introduction of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also explores changes in brand ownership and rankings. Additional information includes links to articles on what China owns, freezing food tips, and a BBC Good Food Annual survey ranking the top 20 consumer brands in the UK. The video is best viewed in full screen.

The passage describes two incidents of elderly women being tricked by callers claiming to be from BT technical support. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was deceived on 15 September. In the second incident, a woman in Stranraer lost money to a caller who gained remote access to her computer seven days later. PC Siobhan Pellett warns about the alarming ease with which these scammers access victims' computers and emphasizes the substantial sums being taken. She advises people to be extremely cautious when answering cold calls that request remote access to their computers and reiterates that banks and reputable businesses never ask for banking details over the phone.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract with the third-placed Championship team after departing Swinton Lions. The Scotland assistant coach will manage Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday ahead of the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy, highlighting his impressive work at Swinton under challenging conditions. Duffy, who had a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been succeeded by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The rider, who had head injuries and was very cold from being unconscious on wet sand, was treated on-site before being airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to allocate a radio frequency for a global flight tracking system to improve upon the current ground-based radar system. This decision followed the disappearance of flight MH370 in March 2014, which highlighted the weaknesses in the existing air navigation system, particularly the coverage gap of around 70% of the world's airspace. The new system will utilize satellite tracking via automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions, enabling real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. The International Civil Aviation Organisation has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, which will require aircraft to send their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

The passage provides information about Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at the age of five and is now 18. He is living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, aged 53, was arrested and is being held at a jail in Ohio. The FBI received a tip on October 30 that Julian might be the long-missing child due to issues he faced while applying for college. The FBI collaborated with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm Julian's identity. His mother has been informed of his recovery. Bobby Hernandez is also charged with tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver's license in 2012. He is held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a bail of $250,000. Authorities had suspected Bobby Hernandez around the time of Julian's disappearance. A missing persons database indicates that Bobby Hernandez claimed to take Julian to pre-school in August 2002 but then fled.

A fire on 2 March at the Duncan Street site caused train service disruptions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste, citing the fire. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) noted that the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, unless an appeal is made by then. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses legislative proposals by the pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia, which are directly linked to the situation in Ukraine, particularly focusing on Crimea. The party has introduced two bills: one that would allow for the annexation of territories from neighbouring states under certain conditions, and another that would expedite the process for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, especially Russian-speaking individuals. The first bill aims to enable the Russian Federation to accept territories where the population expresses a desire to join Russia, bypassing existing treaty requirements. The second bill simplifies and accelerates the passport application process, removing financial and residency requirements, and allowing Ukrainians to apply for Russian citizenship more quickly. These measures are framed as support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians facing what is termed the "brown threat," a reference to World War Two fascists. The proposals come amid strong pro-Russian sentiment in Crimea and have been announced in Sevastopol, the base of the Russian Black Sea Fleet, with support from several Russian MPs and celebrities.

The passage provides a detailed history of McLaren, a once-dominant team in Formula 1 that has experienced a significant decline in recent years. Despite their illustrious past, which includes 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, McLaren now struggles with grid positions and points. The team's recent slump began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, but they have since improved their car, though problems persist with the Honda power-unit. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, with notable successes in the 1980s with Honda and in the late 1990s with Mika Hakkinen. However, scandals and internal issues have plagued the team in recent years. Despite current difficulties, team principal Ron Dennis remains optimistic about McLaren's future, believing that success is imminent and that the team will eventually break Mercedes' dominance in F1. Fernando Alonso's return to McLaren in 2015 was partly motivated by the hope of winning a third championship with the team's renewed Honda partnership. Dennis and his team are hopeful that progress will soon lead to multiple championships again, but for now, they are relying on belief and hope for a resurgence.

Thomas Baker, also known as Tommy, was found injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January and later died in hospital after being shot in the head and chest. Three Liverpool men, aged 29 and 32, have been arrested and are in police custody. Detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside Phoenix Gym for about an hour before the attack. Merseyside Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and are urging several people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward as they may have crucial information.

The passage provides a summary of various online and digital initiatives aimed at making Christmas more spiritual without sacrificing modern conveniences. Key points include:

1. **Everyday Church Online**: A UK-based service offering virtual Sunday services streamed globally, with a Christmas theme centered around Star Wars, drawing spiritual parallels to Christmas.
   
2. **Guardians of Ancora**: A free-to-play fantasy game for children that incorporates Bible stories to combat darkness in a fictional world called Ancora.

3. **Nativity Videos**: Innovative digital nativity stories, such as Viral.de's "The Digital Story of Nativity" told through social media updates and the Churches Advertising Network's "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle."

4. **Next Manga**: A company distributing Bible stories in Manga form, including a special version of the nativity called the Manga Messiah, aimed at sharing hope and peace, especially with refugees.

5. **Social Media Engagement**: Groups using platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to share spiritual messages, with a focus on brevity and modern communication methods.

These initiatives aim to blend traditional spiritual themes with contemporary digital and social media formats to engage people during the Christmas season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is assessing a proposal to develop a circuit on 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land. Supporters, including Blaenau Gwent council, have proposed offering around 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. Experts have provided conflicting views on whether the circuit would harm local habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales found it hard to determine if the replacement land was of equal value but did not outright oppose the development. However, the developers' ecology report claimed a "net gain" in biodiversity due to planned enhancements to nearby habitats, a stance contested by the Gwent wildlife trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will provide a recommendation following the inquiry, after which Welsh government ministers will make the final decision on the project's approval.

The passage describes a series of events following a report by Novaya Gazeta on 1 April, which detailed the detention and alleged killings of over 100 people suspected of being homosexual in Chechnya. In response, Chechen Muslim clerics convened on 3 April and condemned the report, calling for "retribution" against its instigators. Novaya Gazeta interpreted this as a call for reprisals against its journalists. The paper urged Russian authorities to prevent actions inciting hatred towards its journalists. The Russian LGBT Network corroborated the report's claims and reported detainees were subjected to torture. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, while his spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, confirmed the call for retribution. Novaya Gazeta's editor vowed to continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya despite the threats. The passage also mentions the unsolved murders of previous Novaya Gazeta reporters investigating crimes in Chechnya and the LGBT Network's plan to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute the abuses.

The passage describes a controversial arrangement between Investing Solutions, a company, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, both founded by Samir Patel. Investing Solutions has been receiving housing benefits by finding properties for single homeless men, primarily over the age of 35. The company profits by charging housing benefits for each tenant rather than passing the bulk of the rent to private landlords. This practice has led to higher total benefit payouts compared to the rent paid to landlords, generating significant profits. For instance, Investing Solutions claimed £2,114 per month in housing benefit for two tenants, while the landlord received £1,150, resulting in an annual gross profit of £11,568 from one property. Critics, including a homeless group and a homeless charity, argue this is exploitative and a "new low." Despite this, neither the charity nor the company is acting illegally. Fresh Start Housing claims to refer clients to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. The arrangement has drawn substantial funding from Wandsworth Council, which has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1 million in the past two years. The Department for Communities and Local Government asserts that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money through dedicated investigations and inspections.

In a closely contested game, London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 for Great Britain (GB). Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters but was overtaken by the Netherlands in the last 10 minutes. The Netherlands ultimately won, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points. Despite the loss, Prunty praised Gordon's performance, especially his three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter. Prunty emphasized the importance of maintaining intensity in every play for the upcoming Eurobasket qualifiers, starting with a game in Hungary.

The passage details the submission of a waiver by former five-weight world champion Conor McGregor to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) regarding the use of lighter gloves for his upcoming fight against Floyd Mayweather. The NAC, which is responsible for sanctioning the bout, anticipated McGregor's request and will debate the use of 8oz gloves on August 16. While lighter gloves are less cushioning but potentially more punishing, NAC rules generally require 10oz gloves for fights at 154 lbs. McGregor's UFC background, where he has used 4oz gloves, and his notable boxing skills, demonstrated by knocking down Nate Diaz multiple times, have influenced the NAC's consideration. The NAC's executive director, Bob Bennett, emphasized the importance of fighter safety but cited several reasons to potentially approve the fight, including McGregor's age, physical attributes, and recent sparring sessions. The NAC will make a public decision after the debate.

The passage recounts the decline of Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, through the experiences of reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith from the Dundee-based Sunday Post. Fleet Street, historically synonymous with major newspapers, saw its prominence wane as most national papers moved away due to new printing technologies and disputes like the one led by Rupert Murdoch in 1986. The passage highlights the street's storied past, marked by bustling newsrooms, socialising in pubs, and the significant role newspapers played in public information before the rise of television and social media. With the departure of the Sunday Post's last journalists, Fleet Street's era as a journalistic hub has officially ended, though its historical significance remains.

The passage discusses the author's reflections on the global perspective and the prevalence of decent people, despite facing abusive comments on Twitter. The Harry Potter author, who previously tweeted about her "personal line [having] been crossed" by some abusive comments, emphasized her stance against bullies. She faced criticism on Twitter for her political donations, including a £1m donation to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum and a similar amount to the Labour party in 2008. Recently, she revealed she had been called "a traitor" for her political views and had blocked some abusive Twitter users, asserting she feels no responsibility to protect any political party's image from such behavior. She also mentioned having positive interactions with some SNP supporters and joked about bringing marshmallows in response to a suggestion that her books should be burned. The SNP became the third largest party in the UK after winning 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland in the recent election.

The passage summarizes a study by University of Edinburgh researchers which found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action compared to better-off children who commit the same crime. The study, known as the Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime, tracked 4,300 young people since 1998 and revealed that poverty significantly increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. Specifically, poorer young people were about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their wealthier peers. The study also highlighted that people living in extreme poverty were more likely to be both victims and perpetrators of crime. Gender was identified as a powerful predictor of violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds being twice as likely as those from affluent households to be involved in violent crime, even after accounting for other risk factors. The findings suggest a destructive cycle where poverty increases the risks of violence, and contact with the juvenile justice system further exacerbates these risks. Additionally, another study by the University of Edinburgh indicated that despite overall falling crime rates, areas with the highest chronic crime rates remain in the most deprived communities, raising questions about inequality and its tackling by the Scottish government. The Scottish government, however, asserts that it is making Scotland safer with a record low in crime and increased investment in tackling poverty and inequalities.

In the early hours of Sunday, 25-year-old Karl Haugh was stabbed to death in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee. Robbie Walsh, from Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody to appear in court next week. Two other men arrested in connection with the incident were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. According to Det Sgt Padraig Frawley, Walsh and two other men allegedly entered the Marian Estate looking for Haugh, where a fight ensued involving multiple individuals, resulting in Haugh's fatal stab wound. Gardaí recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene, and a knife blade with blood was found. Haugh was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. The judge noted community tension due to the killing.

The passage describes a legal case involving Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan, who tweeted a controversial joke suggesting that Tom Elliott, a member of the Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR) and now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, had harassed and shot people. The tweet was reported to Elliott by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour but was later required to post an apology stating that his comments were "untrue and wholly without foundation." The insurance firm for MLAs at Stormont refused to cover Flanagan for any compensation and costs, a decision he is challenging separately. Mr Justice Stevens has reserved judgment on the compensation amount. Elliott expressed satisfaction with the vindication and disappointment about the prolonged legal process.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with a history dating back to 1874 and currently employing over 230 staff, has ramped up its sweater production to 9,500 per week from 7,500 last year due to strong demand. This increase follows the successful launch of its branded range in January and growth in its private label business. The company, recently acquired by managing director Benny Hartop, sells to markets across Europe and internationally in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop expressed optimism about the company's future, attributing the success to the dedicated staff.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston after being struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, a beloved figure and mother-of-three, is now in residential care. The incident occurred when Wright's car failed to stop at a red light while Mrs. Blackburn was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road. Wright expressed remorse, acknowledging the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a NATO exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose" aimed at countering the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy's HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat, U33, which is attempting to evade detection and simulate an attack on a command ship and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights Britain's vulnerability due to the lack of its own maritime patrol aircraft, a gap that has necessitated reliance on NATO allies for surveillance. The passage underscores the increasing military strength of Russia, which has invested heavily in advanced submarines, and the challenges NATO faces in anti-submarine warfare. The exercise also marks the first deployment of NATO underwater drones and a French maritime patrol aircraft to assist in the search, emphasizing the need for advanced technology and international cooperation to address these threats.

The passage discusses the escalating ethnic violence in South Sudan, which has led to a massive refugee crisis. Since violence erupted in Juba in July and spread to the southern Equatoria states, over 340,000 people have fled to neighboring Uganda, more than any other country this year. The United Nations warns that genocide and ethnic cleansing could be imminent. The violence involves targeted killings, rape, and ethnic targeting, particularly between the Dinka and Nuer tribes. Many refugees, including children, have walked long distances to reach Uganda, where they receive aid and are provided land to start farming. Despite the initial generosity, Uganda is now struggling to manage the large influx of refugees, especially in supplying water. The UNHCR calls for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence. The passage highlights the resilience of the refugees, exemplified by a young girl's poem despite her traumatic experiences.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old former footballer turned professional boxer in 2013, will compete against Jahmaine Smyle on 12 November at York Hall for the English super-middleweight championship. He has a professional boxing record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, the former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage outlines a £330m investment by a coalition for new NHS facilities in England, with £33m allocated for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray services, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped, requiring frequent repairs. Matron Sue Taylor emphasized the positive impact of a modern facility on patient well-being. In the past five years, three of Somerset's community hospitals have been replaced, and work has begun on a new building at Musgrove Park Hospital. Dr. Donal Hynes highlighted the benefits of a modern, one-stop care facility. The new Bridgwater hospital is planned for Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with an aim to complete it by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city centre. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and later died at Northern General hospital. The man was reportedly in or near a black Mercedes when the shooting occurred. Local residents identified him as a family member who was attending a family celebration nearby. Armed police sealed off the area. This incident is part of a series of shootings in Sheffield, though recent ones have been concentrated in the north, not close to Upperthorpe.

The passage provides an overview of various hacker groups involved in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia, focusing on their activities and objectives. Key points include:

1. **Ukrainian Cyber Troops**:
   - Led by Yevhen Dokukin.
   - Use distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks to make rebel websites inaccessible.
   - Target rebel funding through electronic payment systems.
   - Hack into public CCTV systems to monitor troop movements.
   - Claim to have hijacked network printers to print pro-Ukrainian messages.

2. **Cyber Berkut**:
   - An anti-Western group named after riot police used against protesters.
   - Aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and stop what it calls "genocide."
   - Hacked Ukrainian government websites during US Vice-President Joe Biden's visit.
   - Claims to have retrieved confidential documents from Biden's team.
   - Hacked electronic billboards to brand Ukrainian officials as "war criminals."

3. **Anonymous International (b0ltai/Shaltay Boltay)**:
   - Focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but also covers Ukraine.
   - Published a letter suggesting locals did not support separatist forces.
   - Leaked emails from a key rebel commander in eastern Ukraine.
   - Website access blocked in Russia.

The passage also mentions the use of hacked information by Ukraine's security services and denies their use in directing artillery fire.

The passage describes emotional farewells from several veteran MSPs ahead of the upcoming election on May 5. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly moved by speeches from Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the parliament's journey towards greater responsibility, though he criticized the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling unionist pledges. He ended with a heartfelt farewell. McNeil, who has served since the parliament's inception in 1999, warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also joked about her departure. All three are stepping down from their roles.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She aims to gather experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing the voices of older people and those who care for them, highlighting both good and poor care impacts. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira's team will consult care providers, social care staff, and public bodies to ensure accountability and necessary changes for better quality of life in residential care. However, Care Forum Wales expressed disappointment that no care home expert is on the advisory panel, arguing it misses a chance for full sector engagement.

The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported an increase in pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million. The company, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, noted growth in international sales in Europe and new markets. The company remains cautiously optimistic about the future, acknowledging the unpredictability of the agriculture sector and the uncertain impact of Brexit, but confident in its preparedness for any challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was taken to the hospital. Detectives are seeking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned the public not to approach him. The investigation is in its early stages, but the death is being treated as murder. Ian McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt. Police are urging anyone with information to contact them and have increased patrols in the area.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, highlighted risks in a speech, noting a weakening global economy and a delicate juncture. This follows disappointing trade data from China, where exports dropped significantly. The IMF anticipates downgrading its global growth forecast from 3.4% when it updates its predictions in April. This bleak outlook has implications for businesses relying on China's economic growth.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with the new vessel, a chain ferry that launched on 14 May. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July to gather feedback and acknowledge the problems. The council ordered a project review by auditors, noting a "frustrating and disappointing start" due to breakdowns, groundings, and training issues. Local businesses, including shopkeeper Angie Booth, expressed concerns about lost trade. Transport councillor Ian Ward suggested compensation for local businesses and mentioned that while there were initial teething problems, including electrical issues and vehicle damage, these were being addressed. The council authorized ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage and resolved grounding issues related to seamanship.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene, and a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Matching Models, an international temp agency that emphasizes looks in its job advertisements. The agency advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, which the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) deemed "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women." The EHRC's chief executive, Rebecca Hilsenrath, criticized the agency and announced they would seek clarification on its hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners also condemned the ads as outdated and likely violating equality legislation. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, stating that looks are important to their clients. The passage also mentions another job advert seeking a "sexy female driver," which an employment lawyer deemed "clearly unlawful." The EHRC and employment lawyers argue that such ads are discriminatory and unlawful under the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on various personal attributes. Despite the criticism, Jansen highlighted the agency's clients, which include major brands like MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods.

A shooting took place at a hostel connected to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where the alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, shot 18-year-old Gautami, killing her, and severely injured another student, Sirisha, who is expected to recover. The motive for the shooting remains unclear. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until April 12. Gun crime in educational institutions in India is rare, though firearms are often used to settle disputes. In a notable past incident, a 14-year-old schoolboy was killed by fellow students in 2007 near Delhi.

The advocacy group Glaad's analysis of shows aired between June 2016 and May 2017 found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, Glaad noted that more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including notable characters from "Orange is the New Black" and "Wentworth." The study also highlighted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like "Empire," "Luke Cage," and "How to Get Away with Murder." Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged the progress but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the whole story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to face opposition. This decision comes amid criticism over millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC, which now appears to have vanished. The loan, which was arranged when Mackintosh was the borough council leader to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, is now missing by about £10.25m and is under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. The football stand remains half-built. Despite previously intending to stand for re-election, Mackintosh stated that he felt it was the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

In April, Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fired a rifle into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Dallas, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault. Police had responded to reports of underage drinking at the party. Initial claims that the car reversed aggressively towards Oliver were discredited by footage showing it driving away. Oliver faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted, which would mark the first police murder conviction in Dallas County since 1973. No trial date has been set, and his lawyer has not commented. The Dallas County DA's office emphasized the importance of thorough justice proceedings. The Edwards family's lawyer noted the rarity of police being convicted in Texas.

The passage discusses Melania Trump's decision to delay moving to Washington, D.C., with her son Barron until after he finishes the school year, which has sparked criticism and speculation on social media. Transition spokesman Jason Miller emphasized the Trumps' excitement about their new role but did not address the criticism directly. Historically, only two First Ladies have not resided in the White House during their husbands' presidencies, and there are precedents for children not immediately moving to the White House. Historians note that it is not unusual for children to stay behind to finish school, citing examples like Frances Folsom Cleveland, Chelsea Clinton, and Malia and Sasha Obama. The passage also touches on the ceremonial and public role of the First Lady, referencing the active roles taken by predecessors like Michelle Obama and Hillary Clinton, and the more private approach of Nancy Reagan. It speculates on whether Ivanka Trump might take on some responsibilities for her stepmother, Melania Trump, and mentions precedents of daughters performing some First Lady duties. The passage concludes by highlighting how the White House can reflect the family's dynamics, with examples from Chelsea Clinton and the Obamas.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), led by Kate Frame, has been tasked with scrutinizing the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and awaits its findings. Pirc will submit a report to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) with its findings.

The passage issued a yellow wind warning indicating gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) could occur, especially west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly wind direction potentially intensifying the impact. Travel disruption on roads and at sea is anticipated. The affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for cleanup.

The passage describes a hockey match between the Giants and the Panthers. The game started with Derrick Walser scoring for the Giants, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal, making it 2-1, followed by Andy Bohmback's equalizer. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored for the Giants, making it 4-2, before David Ling scored for the Panthers. The passage concludes by mentioning that the teams will meet again on Saturday night and notes that Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Lewis Hamilton, the world champion, started the race from the back due to a broken front wing on lap one and made five pit stops. Despite his efforts, he faces a significant challenge to close a 36-point gap in the remaining 18 races. Sebastian Vettel finished second after a collision with his Ferrari teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, which damaged both cars. Raikkonen recovered to fifth place, passing Hamilton towards the end of the race, aided by Ferrari's choice of soft tyres. Hamilton remains confident he can reduce Nico Rosberg's lead but historically, no driver who wins the first three races has failed to win the championship. The race began chaotically with multiple collisions on the first lap, leading to a safety car deployment. Rosberg ultimately won the race, while Hamilton's car damage and multiple pit stops hindered his progress.

In an interview with Die Zeit, former footballer Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly revealed his homosexuality, becoming the most prominent footballer to do so in Germany. His announcement was met with widespread support from his former teammates, including Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as leading figures in German football administration such as Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball. The announcement was hailed as a significant step in the fight against homophobia in football, with Bundesliga president Rauball calling it a "huge and courageous step." The revelation is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, where homophobia in football has been a persistent issue. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman Steffen Seibert praised Hitzlsperger for addressing an important issue, and openly gay German politician Volker Beck hoped it would encourage others to come out. Theo Zwanziger expressed optimism that Hitzlsperger's announcement would lead to greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played a key role in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years, making 32 Championship appearances this season. With his contract set to expire, he is keen to sign a new deal, expressing his desire to help the team stay in the Premier League. Brighton's recent win over Wigan confirmed their promotion, and they are now aiming to secure the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell previously played for several Premier League clubs and believes he has performed well and deserves another opportunity at the top level. He hopes to finalize a new contract if one is offered.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead early on when Jamille Matt turned home a cross from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalised from a corner scramble with Kurtis Guthrie. Blackpool had chances to win the game, including a save by goalkeeper Sam Slocombe and a missed header by Tom Aldred. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister. The final score was Blackpool 1, Colchester United 1.

The passage provides information about a 29-year-old player who made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. The player, Reid, has previous stints with Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He might debut for Colchester United in the upcoming EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester began the season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington. For more football transfer news, there is a dedicated page available.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March has led to a greater emphasis on creating a permanent memorial for police officers and staff. The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising £1.5m for a memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will honor more than 1,400 officers and staff who have died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The memorial will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out for the families of fallen officers, personalized with the names of their loved ones. The Home Secretary has committed £1m of the £4m needed for the project, which is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League table with eight games left after a 1-0 victory over Sunderland. Manager Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on the upcoming matches rather than their record of 25 wins in the first 30 matches. The team is preparing for a derby against Manchester City and aims to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record from 2005. Ferguson mentioned potential changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea. He also noted that Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley were not started against Sunderland due to fatigue. Despite injuries, Ferguson praised the team's determined defending and courage in securing the win.

In a BBC interview, Mr. Schmidt defended Google's payment of £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, stating that the company complied with all legally required tax obligations. He emphasized that it is the government's responsibility to modify the tax system if it wishes for companies to pay more. Schmidt argued that taxes should be viewed as legally required and not optional, and that Google would adjust its tax payments in line with any changes in UK tax laws. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge proposed establishing a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, aiming to ensure transparency. Google, which routes most of its UK sales through Ireland, has faced criticism for tax minimization strategies. The EU has also agreed to monitor tax avoidance through automatic information exchange among tax authorities. Schmidt has advocated for international tax reform and believes that politicians, not companies, should set the tax rules.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce the agency bill by £1bn by the end of the financial year, down from £3.6bn spent last year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far, limiting payments to no more than 55% above normal rates for staff, except senior managers. While progress is promising, NHS trusts are still 10% short of their target. The cap does not cover NHS "bank" staff or overtime costs. NHS Improvement plans to publish "league tables" of trusts' agency spending and will collect data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust to address suspicions of excessive earnings. Examples were found of hospitals being quoted double the capped rates for doctors.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a hub of commerce, now symbolizes the aftermath of the Celtic Tiger economic crash in the Republic of Ireland. Despite the downturn, local traders like Matt O'Brien of a family-owned men's clothing shop observe a gradual recovery, noting increased business over the past year. Fianna Fáil criticizes the government's handling of the region, particularly a half-billion euro investment in non-operational water meters instead of broadband improvements. The government counters with plans for a Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon, which is expected to create 1,000 jobs upon completion in 2019, pending planning permission. While this project is seen as promising, local traders like O'Brien suggest that more could be done to boost business, including addressing parking fees and competition from neighboring towns. Overall, the Midlands show signs of economic recovery but acknowledge that further efforts are needed.

The passage provides an overview of a cricket competition featuring eight teams, with each team playing the others twice. The top four teams will advance to the play-offs. Key statistics include leading run-scorers (Warner with 294, Kohli with 267, De Villiers with 249), most sixes (Warner and De Villiers with 12 each, Kohli with 8), the highest score in an innings (De Kock with 108), and most wickets (McClenaghan with 9, Kumar with 8, Rahman with 7). Four current or former England players participate: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The competition concludes on 29 May with the final in the same stadium. Fixtures and results can be followed via BBC Sport.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013. Many of these bags cannot be recycled and end up in rubbish dumps and rivers, causing environmental harm. Starting in October, people in England will be charged 5p for plastic bags to encourage reuse. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, which already charge for bags, have seen a decrease in usage. Environmental campaigners hope the new charge in England will similarly reduce waste and benefit the environment.

The passage describes severe weather conditions across Wales on a particular Friday, including a ripped school roof in Rhosgadfan, widespread power cuts, train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and cancellations of Irish Ferries sailings due to high winds. The day followed a yellow wind warning and coincided with the busy Christmas getaway. The highest wind gusts were recorded on Anglesey. The National Trust closed two historic sites due to expected high winds. Although wind restrictions eased in the evening, a blustery forecast led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip.

The passage mentions that Michael B. Jordan expressed his excitement about a new project, hinting at a different role but not specifying what it is. He is set to reunite with his Creed director, Ryan Coogler, and looks forward to collaborating with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot, while Nyong'o won an Oscar for her role in 12 Years a Slave and voiced Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The film in question is Black Panther, set for release in February 2018.

The passage describes a restoration project for Alexandra Palace's theatre and BBC studios, founded in 1875, which aims to be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The theatre and studios are part of a larger east wing restoration project to turn Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The project, costing £26.6m, is funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, which aims to raise the remaining £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, unused for decades but retaining much of its original decor and stage machinery, was originally designed for opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings. The goal is to reopen the theatre in 2018 if fundraising is successful.

The passage provides information about a former Manchester City player who is 30 years old and has earned 61 caps for the England national team since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, although he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. The player, who also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win against Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. The player expressed well wishes for the future of the England team and its staff.

Marcy Smith and her family's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was completely destroyed by a fire that started from rubbish burned in the wood stove. Their son David woke them up, allowing the whole family to escape, though their pets did not survive. David was on FaceTime with his father when he noticed the flames and quickly alerted his family. The fire alarm did not go off, and the family fled in their pajamas. The community has since supported them by donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Mrs. Smith credits David for saving their lives and plans to remind him of his heroic actions.

The passage discusses the potential interest of an energy drinks company in making a £200m offer for the Premier League club West Ham United. Sullivan and Gold acquired a majority stake in West Ham in 2010, valuing the club at £105m, and now own over 85% of it. Since relocating to the London Stadium in August, West Ham has also been rumored to be a target for takeovers by Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority stake to clear debts, although he and Gold plan for the ownership to eventually pass to their children.

The passage describes a fan-voted awards ceremony featuring various categories such as best kiss, best shirtless performance, and best movie. The big winner was "The Fault in Our Stars," which won best movie, and Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for "American Sniper," while Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for "22 Jump Street." Meryl Streep won best villain for "Into the Woods." Other notable winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award, bringing his kids on stage. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, with his Avengers co-stars presenting it to him. Clips from upcoming films like "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Avengers: Ultron" were also shown.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances for the club. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, praised the acquisition, highlighting Smith's maturity and potential to strengthen the attacking options. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will face Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that its Jetpatcher machines will now be used to fill potholes due to the warmer weather. The council aims to repair 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be working on fixing drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clearing debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while performing shutdown work. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes reported that they were not provided with proper personal protective equipment (PPE) and were exposed to radiation for hours. EnQuest confirmed the incident and stated that the exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level, but they took additional precautionary steps and informed the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). Wood Group, the contracting company, emphasized its commitment to employee safety and conducted medical assessments. The Unite union criticized the handling of the incident, stressing the importance of transparency for worker safety. The HSE noted that the incident was not reportable under current regulations and no separate investigation was conducted.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past. The dealer's manager later confessed to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this sculpture, which is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The museum decided to return the sculpture following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which requested its return. Although there is no conclusive proof of the sculpture's theft, ACM noted the manager's confession about dealing in looted antiquities. The museum plans to take legal action to seek compensation for the purchase.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicenter in Garfagnana. The tremor was felt in cities including Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in Garfagnana, and schools were evacuated as a precaution. This event follows a history of seismic activity in the region, including a deadly magnitude-6 quake in May of the previous year and a 2009 earthquake in L'Aquila that killed almost 300 people. Italy's National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV) described the recent quake as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow."

The passage mentions that as of 8 September 2016, fruit is still on the plant and not ripe. Austin Grant from Sheffield, who was initially skeptical about South Yorkshire's climate, has now seen some positive results, leading him to express his joy.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest version of the open world adventure game until 24 March, pushing back from its original release date of 27 January. The company stated that the delay is to allow for additional testing and polishing to ensure the game's quality. Rockstar emphasized that this decision was made in the best interests of the game and its fans. Additionally, the company announced that online heists will debut on consoles before the PC release. Screenshots from the PC version showcase enhanced detail, with graphics support for up to 4K resolution and triple monitor setups. Minimum PC specifications for running GTA V have been released. The original Grand Theft Auto V became the fastest-selling entertainment product in history, earning $1bn in revenue within three days of its release on 17 September 2013.

The passage highlights that a 76-year-old artist, Simpson, has won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. Simpson, who has been longlisted for the prize multiple times, expressed his delight at finally winning. Judge Ansel Krut praised the painting as "quite extraordinary" despite its challenging nature. The painting depicts a leper squint, a feature in medieval churches allowing lepers to observe services. Simpson noted that the relatively small size of the piece was one reason he entered it into the competition. He plans to use the prize money for art materials, particularly high-quality paints. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with notable past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The passage reports that the offices of two Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked by masked assailants. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously early Thursday, with gunfire shattering windows in both buildings. Firefighters swiftly put out a resulting blaze, and no casualties were reported. Istanbul police found numerous spent bullet casings at both sites and have cordoned off the area. The two papers support the governing AK Party led by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The Yeni Akit offices are located 20km away from the Yeni Safak building. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks, and police are currently searching for the assailants. This incident echoes a similar attack last September on the offices of another pro-government newspaper, Hurriyet.

A 24-year-old player, previously contracted with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer starting January 1. He had a loan spell at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 games. This signing marks Bignot's first acquisition for the Mariners.

The passage discusses Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger's views on Gareth Southgate's potential as England's national team manager. Wenger praises Southgate's experience and competency, noting that Southgate has a chance to prove his quality through upcoming matches. Wenger also addresses his own potential link to the England manager role, stating he focuses on his current job. Additionally, Wenger confirms that Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin, who has attracted interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, will be offered a new contract, and mentions that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will be out for "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and Fruehauf is fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union alleged that some workers on two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour. The new charter will revert contracted out services to operator Serco Northlink starting next month. The vessels Hellier and Hildasay were previously operated by Seatruck, which argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to non-UK resident crew members. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap retroactively, but Seatruck declined. The new arrangements, set to take effect early next month pending final financial and regulatory details, will ensure all crew members receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink holds a £243m six-year contract for services to the Northern Isles, which includes three ferries and two cargo boats, heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, leading to a confrontation. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and his mother and he also admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a prolific British songwriter known for his low profile, passed away in London at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Temperton was renowned for his contributions to Michael Jackson's albums, including writing three songs for "Off The Wall" and three for "Thriller," which helped make the latter the best-selling album of all time in the US. His other notable works include songs for his band Heatwave and tracks recorded by artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Aretha Franklin. Temperton won a Grammy for his work on Quincy Jones's "Birdland" and was nominated for two Oscars for the soundtrack of "The Color Purple." Tributes poured in from fellow musicians, including Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson. Temperton's private funeral has taken place, and his family has requested privacy during this time.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader from Swansea University and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, has discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon. These ditched enclosures, now revealed by deforestation, comprise over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs." The purpose of these sites remains unclear, though they are unlikely to have been villages or defensive structures due to the lack of artifacts and unusual layout. They may have been used sporadically for rituals, akin to the Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Dr. Loader's analysis of soil samples suggests these geoglyphs were built under taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy, raising questions about their purpose. The research also challenges the notion that the Amazonian forests were untouched before European arrival, indicating human influence over 6,000 years through "agroforestry" practices, concentrating on valuable trees. This suggests a legacy of these ancient practices may still be evident in the region's biodiversity.

The Australian tennis player, aged 21 and currently ranked a career-high 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round. The player, who recently won the Japan Open, attributed his subdued performance to fatigue and travel exhaustion. He mentioned feeling tired and not having the best sleep due to the travel involved in playing at the Qi Zhong Stadium, an hour from Shanghai city centre. This tournament also holds a previous incident where the player was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst last year.

The passage discusses the potential of the HPV vaccine to protect against head and neck cancers, which are on the rise, particularly among younger men. The current vaccination program targets girls aged 12 and 13 to prevent cervical cancer. Charities and organizations, including Tenovus Cancer Care and Cardiff University's HPV research team, are urging the Welsh government to expand the vaccination to boys to combat the increasing number of head and neck cancer cases. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes to the current HPV vaccination program, which has already vaccinated 85% of girls in Wales since its introduction in 2008.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School student, bravely fought a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Despite his illness, he attended a school prom held in his honor, though he had to leave early due to feeling unwell. Jak documented his journey and treatment on a Facebook page called "Jak's Journey," which garnered over 28,000 likes and showcased his positive attitude and love for Rangers FC. He received numerous awards and support from his community, including a Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. On January 23, doctors informed Jak that his cancer had spread, leading to the decision to cease further treatment. Jak passed away, and his mother announced the news on Facebook, expressing her pride and love for him. Efforts to raise funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research continue, including a special football match at Livingston FC's home ground.

In a largely uneventful match, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda thanks to a goal by Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had an earlier goal by Joseph Ochaya disallowed for offside. The win keeps Egypt's hopes alive for the top spot in Group D, setting up a crucial match against Ghana. Uganda, on the other hand, is eliminated from the tournament, their first absence since 1978. Ghana had already qualified for the quarter-finals with a win over Mali. The game was played on a deteriorating pitch in Port-Gentil, where Egypt struggled to break down Uganda's defense. Uganda had some promising moments but failed to register a shot on target. The match ended with Egypt winning 1-0.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for potential railway station development. Both sites have been unused; the sports college closed in August, and the Westbank campus of Skelmersdale College, owned by Newcastle College, is also vacant.
