This decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail of these sites and another near the Concourse shopping centre. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans for Skelmersdale to get two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County councillor John Fillis, cabinet member for highways and transport, described the plan as "exciting" and noted the site's potential for future expansion, good highway access, and connectivity. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station.
A man in his late 40s was arrested on Saturday morning after police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old unidentified woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement after reportedly being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was taken to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, later turned himself in to authorities. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack remains unclear, according to Hannover prosecutors. Police have secured the scene and are urging witnesses to come forward.

The research conducted by the Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women are just as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are less likely to receive one. The study, which analyzed data from 4,600 workers, found no support for the "reticent female" theory, indicating that women do not avoid asking for higher pay. The study uniquely compared full-time male and female workers, as well as part-time male and female workers, to eliminate the impact of part-time work on pay differences. It revealed that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked compared to women. The research also debunked the idea that women avoid asking for raises due to fear of upsetting their boss or conforming to stereotypes. Factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications were considered. The study, based on the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, suggests that discrimination against women may be a contributing factor. Notably, younger women under 40 were found to negotiate pay rises as successfully as men of the same age, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behavior.

Oxford City Council has spent money on investigating potential new burial sites but has not found any suitable locations. The two existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council continues to search for new options but has exhausted all council-owned sites due to various factors like size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants. Once the current cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, reserved plots, and ashes interment will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews from festival signs and posters. The app will enable global interaction with the festival's atmosphere, providing instant access to information, interviews, ticket purchases, and a unique festival experience. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan highlights the app as an additional feature to enhance festival enjoyment.

The passage describes the tragic death of a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds, who collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite veterinary treatment, he was pronounced dead due to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Tony Welsh from the British Horseracing Authority noted that such incidents are rare and can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia, where he would overheat and wobble, but had shown no such symptoms on the day of his death. Trainer Oliver Sherwood praised him as the "horse of a lifetime." The report concludes that Many Clouds' death was due to a haemorrhage, not linked to his previous health issues.

The passage describes a case involving Davina Ayrton, who is accused of raping a 15-year-old girl in Portsmouth in 2004. Davina, now 34, denies the charge and is awaiting sentencing on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely to be held in a male prison in Winchester due to concerns she would be a risk to herself and might fail to attend court. The court noted Ayrton's learning difficulties and a previous suicide attempt. Protocols have been established for her detention. Ayrton, who changed her name in 2012, admitted to the attack in 2014 to a care home worker. The victim, who had only drunk a small amount of alcohol, remembered the assault and shouted at Ayrton to stop, though her friends did not wake up.

The passage provides a summary of Novak Djokovic's recent tennis performances. It mentions that the Serbian team, including Djokovic, lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss followed Djokovic's defeat in the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Additionally, Djokovic experienced a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July against American Sam Querrey. Despite these setbacks, Djokovic reclaimed his status by winning his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

A competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, will feature over 20 competitors carving logs into animal and human shapes using only chainsaws. Participants hail from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, has not played since a serious foot injury in September during a World Cup warm-up match with Italy. He is nearing a return and is currently in a pre-season training phase, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations starting in February. Webb has extended his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, rejecting offers from other teams to stay with his home region. He plans to take each week as it comes and is optimistic about his recovery. Wales' Six Nations campaign begins on February 7 against Ireland in Dublin.

The passage describes an incident where US border agents intercepted two men near the Canadian border, suspecting them of smuggling MDMA (ecstasy) to San Francisco. One man fired at the agents and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately taken into custody. Canadian and US police conducted a search for the fugitive, Nathan Hall, who was later arrested in British Columbia. The backpacks carried by Hall and Laviolette contained 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy. Additionally, Kali Henifin and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert were arrested for their alleged roles in the drug transport scheme. The three defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is notorious for drug and firearm smuggling.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in the number of children seeking counseling, rising from about 2,400 in 2011-12 to over 4,500 in the past year. The charity highlighted that online abuse is a major issue, with some children as young as seven sharing their experiences of being tormented and scared to go to school due to cyber-bullying. Dame Esther Rantzen emphasized the need for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children, noting that bullying often escalates if left unchecked. The report coincides with the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which aims to combat bullying through collaboration with parents, schools, and other organizations. Young people have shared that even seemingly minor bullying can have severe emotional impacts, and advice includes seeking help from adults.

The passage describes Israel's response to a UN Security Council resolution condemning settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which Israel views as part of its capital. The resolution, which Israel rejected, was passed with the US abstaining rather than vetoing it, which angered Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Netanyahu's office accused the White House of drafting the resolution, a claim denied by the US State Department. In response to the resolution, Netanyahu recalled Israel's ambassadors from two countries, cut aid to one, and cancelled a visit by another country's prime minister. To avoid further straining relations with Washington ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Israel postponed a planned vote on authorizing new homes in two settlements. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution, hoping it would lead to a peace conference in France aimed at ending the occupation.

The passage provides a summary of the events surrounding Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, highlighting tributes and celebrations. Key points include:

1. **Tributes and Celebrations**: Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch in a BBC interview. Stamps featuring the Queen and the Royal Family were released to mark her birthday.
   
2. **Queen's Activities**: The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, marking the 500th anniversary of the postal service. She then attended a ceremony to open a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens, where children sang Happy Birthday.

3. **Political Tributes**: Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their wishes for the Queen's birthday.

4. **Prince William's Views**: William addressed criticisms of his commitment to royal duties, stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but is finding his own way. He sees the Queen as his best role model.

5. **Birthday Stamps**: Ten stamps were released, including images of four generations of the Royal Family and stamps focusing on the Queen's family life and official role.

6. **Future Plans**: The Queen will light a beacon on her actual birthday, unveiling a 6.3km walking trail named The Queen's Walkway. On Friday, she will have lunch with President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama at Windsor Castle.

7. **Republican Criticism**: The republican group Republic criticized the BBC for excessive celebration rather than fair reporting of the Queen's birthday.

In a match between League Two's Cheltenham Town and Premier League's West Ham United, West Ham took control early with two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew before halftime. Cheltenham had chances but failed to capitalize, with notable attempts from Harry Pell and Jordon Forster. West Ham could have extended their lead but also missed opportunities. The match ended with West Ham winning 2-0, advancing while Cheltenham exited the EFL Cup. This was the second meeting between the two sides in this competition's same stage, with West Ham previously winning 2-1 four years ago.

The passage describes a fatal collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion where hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died. Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, failed to see McNicholl's motorcycle as he turned his VW Transporter, causing the crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not support jail time for Werner, accepting it was a momentary lapse. Werner's defense stated he was remorseful and could not explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, west London, attempted to return to the UK last year after fighting in Syria with the group Rayat al Tawheed, affiliated with Islamic State. Known for his online presence while masked, Khawaja was involved in producing propaganda videos and appeals for donations. Despite his involvement in gruesome activities, including holding a bag containing a severed head, his exact role and intentions remain unclear. Khawaja tried to sneak back into the UK, faking his death online, but was apprehended by police at Dover. He faces potential life imprisonment for his jihadist activities. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, who assisted his return, has admitted to helping an offender. Khawaja was held in a high-security unit for terrorism suspects and has admitted to four offences, while an additional serious charge of soliciting to murder remains on file.

Jackson, a 22-year-old player, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season as Wrexham finished eighth in the league. Barnsley has signed him as their third acquisition for the upcoming season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and defensive skills, stating he will fit well into Barnsley's playing style. Jackson rejected a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season.

A container of detergent bottles, possibly from the MV Blue Ocean, has washed up on several Cornish beaches including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. The National Trust volunteers are clearing them away due to the risk they pose to wildlife, although some bottles have leaked. While the Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed the MV Blue Ocean lost a container, there is no definitive evidence linking the washed-up bottles to it. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is highly concerned about the impact on marine life. Cornwall Council and partners are monitoring the situation, advising the public to keep children and pets away from the bottles and not to attempt to recover them.

A crash happened on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in several people sustaining minor injuries. The road was closed, and diversions were established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is still investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, played a key role in Bolton Wanderers' promotion to the Championship by making 14 appearances last season as they finished second in League One. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has accumulated 83 appearances in total. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contribution towards the end of the campaign, noting that he was somewhat overlooked but made an excellent impact. Dervite is one of four players, including David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, to sign new contracts with Bolton following their promotion.

The passage discusses tensions between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour in the House of Lords. Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of giving "false hope" to people concerned about their future in Britain, while Labour's Baroness Smith responded that the Lib Dems were prepared to "concede everything." The two parties had previously collaborated to oppose the government on issues related to EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approval. However, their cooperation broke down when MPs rejected amendments, with the Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems' actions as "grandstanding" aimed at campaign material. The Lib Dems' Europe spokesperson, Baroness Ludford, accused Labour of supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. Despite past alliances on various issues, the Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and doubted the likelihood of future cooperation.

The passage highlights the declining priority of defence issues in the current election, despite growing global instability and threats. Defence ranks low among electorate concerns, overshadowed by the economy, NHS, and immigration. UK military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya have contributed to public fatigue and political reluctance to focus on defence. Both major parties' defence policies are sparse and lack detail on the tough decisions ahead. The UK's armed forces are undergoing significant cuts, with reductions in the Army, Royal Navy, and RAF, leading to capability gaps. Defence spending has dropped to sixth globally, and the UK is likely to fall below the NATO 2% GDP defence spending target. Future governments are expected to make further cuts, potentially impacting the Ministry of Defence's budget. The Conservatives and UKIP plan to renew the nuclear deterrent at a high cost, which could be a target for savings. The future of the Trident nuclear programme is uncertain, and the Royal Navy's new aircraft carriers face challenges in manning and equipment. The passage concludes by noting the difficulty in maintaining the UK's military reputation given current budget constraints.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding FC Barcelona's signing of Neymar from Santos. The club insists they have not committed any offense and have made a voluntary tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential interpretations of the fiscal obligations related to the transfer. The total cost to Barcelona for Neymar, including the initial fee, signing-on fee, wages, agents' fees, and the latest tax payment, amounts to £106.8m. The club denies any tax-related crime and maintains that the original tax payment was compliant with fiscal obligations. Additionally, former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money and is under investigation, though he denies any wrongdoing. A Spanish judge has ruled there is enough evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Neymar has performed well for Barcelona, scoring 10 goals in 25 appearances this season.

The passage recounts the tragic death of Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old from Nottingham, who was a passenger in a van that collided with a Mazda Premacy driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was traveling the wrong way on a motorway and also died in the crash. Luciw's family advocates for retired people to undergo regular driving tests, emphasizing the need for safety measures to prevent such incidents. They argue that older drivers' reaction times slow down with age, suggesting mandatory tests with driving instructors. In contrast, Age UK stresses the importance of driving for older people's independence. The UK's current system requires drivers over 70 to renew their licenses every three years via a self-assessment form, without mandatory medical or driving tests. The DVLA asserts there is no evidence older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. The incident has left Luciw's colleague, Andy Harrington, who was driving the van, with lasting trauma and also supports stricter regulations for older drivers.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of mesh implants used to treat incontinence, which have led to debilitating side effects for many women. Two members of the original review group resigned in protest over what they perceived as a diluted report. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will now review the process and conclusions of the report. The report concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended offering a range of treatments with mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the government confirmed the recommendations would continue, noting that a ban would require the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to achieve consensus among panel members. Two women who suffered complications resigned from the review group, expressing dismay over the final report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh implants, with more than 400 currently pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers due to complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Eilish McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, finishing in 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan expressed excitement about her record being broken but raised concerns about the criteria for record ratification, questioning if the race met all UK Athletics' requirements, including the presence of other competitors and drug testing. Despite these concerns, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time is expected to be ratified as an official record. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to win world medals and expects her to run faster times in the future. McColgan also noted similarities between Muir's race and her own record-breaking race, where she also ran alone and lapped other competitors.

In the passage, the core information is that Jung won the competition aboard Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou due to illness. France's Astier Nicolas won silver, and American Phillip Dutton took bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, competing just 10 months after a serious fall that required an induced coma. Fox-Pitt had a faultless final show-jumping but was previously penalized in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also mentions an invitation to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse at Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics and a guide on getting into equestrian sports.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old Briton, defeated Italy's Fabio Fognini in a closely contested match at Wimbledon, winning 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. Despite Fognini's efforts to force a fifth set, Murray won five consecutive games to secure his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week for the first time. Murray noted the match was tense and not his best tennis but was pleased to finish in four sets. Fognini showed both talent and temperament, particularly as the light faded, but ultimately Murray's resilience and improved play in the final set led to his victory.

In October 2014, paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where police later found several people still present. Till receipts indicated alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the 43-year-old license holder, and James Thomas, both from Kevin Lynch Park, were charged for allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The defence highlighted poor adherence to licensing laws and improper management of the premises. The judge expressed concern over the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence, noting O'Neill's "appalling record." O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

In his speech launching the Ulster Unionist Party's manifesto, Mike Nesbitt emphasized that "partnership does" rather than "domination." The party wants the election to focus on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, but attention has shifted to Nesbitt's comments on potentially working with the SDLP post-election, which caused senior colleague Danny Kennedy to distance himself. Nesbitt expressed no regrets and highlighted support in unionist areas. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership,' addresses issues like tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, and supporting the LGBT community, while also calling for "Cleaning Up Stormont" to address incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption. Despite controversy over his SDLP remarks, Nesbitt hopes the manifesto's message will resonate more strongly.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval to implement "Turing's Law," aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales. This law would provide automatic posthumous pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences and allow living men convicted of such offences to apply for pardons. The motion aims to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as their counterparts in England and Wales, with the goal of rectifying past injustices in the criminal justice system. The legislative consent motion will seek to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences and is expected to be passed as soon as possible.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race, finishing in 4:19.12 seconds, which surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60. This achievement also placed her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir expressed her satisfaction with the record and her performance, noting it was her first race of the season over this distance. She aims to secure a spot in the Rio Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham. Muir's training is balanced with her veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
The passage provides images from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as having the best water quality.

In a summary of the passage, Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko, suggesting the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot against him. UK officials believe the two poisoned Litvinenko in London in 2006 with radioactive polonium-210, leading to his death. Horwell emphasized that while the evidence suggests Russian state involvement in Litvinenko's murder, it does not directly implicate President Vladimir Putin. Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his accusations against Putin could have been seen as treacherous by the Russian state. The inquiry highlighted the unknown risks of polonium radiation exposure to the public and noted the failure to extradite Kovtun and Lugovoi from Russia. The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

The passage provides information about the leadership changes in the Australian cricket team. Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the new captain for both the one-day and Twenty20 teams, succeeding Michael Clarke who has decided to retire. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Rod Marsh, the national selector, praised Smith's talent and maturity, while acknowledging Warner's development despite past disciplinary issues. Smith and Warner will lead the team in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test on 20 August.

In a series of interviews, Mr. Farron, the new leader, emphasized his support for LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage, stating that defending equal marriage would be "at the top of my agenda". He expressed a desire to extend marital rights to transgender people, particularly addressing the spousal veto issue. Despite being asked multiple times if he believed homosexual sex was a sin, he refused to provide a direct answer, instead asserting his belief in the inherent sinfulness of all people. He also clarified his vote against the Equality Bill in 2007, explaining that it was due to concerns about the protection of individual liberties, though he did not elaborate on these concerns directly. Overall, he reiterated his commitment to equality under the law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

The passage describes the closure of Sanofi's drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare is now set to use the plant for its pharmaceutical production, with expectations that many of the former Sanofi employees will be rehired. A spokesman for Accord Healthcare expressed confidence in the investment's "extremely positive" impact on the area. Councillor Nick Forbes of Newcastle City Council highlighted the announcement as fantastic news for Newcastle and the North East, emphasizing its role in strengthening the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare is noted for developing, manufacturing, and distributing over 130 pharmaceutical products to approximately 60 countries globally.

The local authority announced that Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, will leave on Friday as his contract ends. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both opting for voluntary redundancy and early retirement. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, commented that these departures reflect the council's struggle to retain senior staff and anticipates more resignations in the near future. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude to the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

The passage discusses the English rider's experience at this year's TT, where he crashed and the Fireblade bike faced mechanical issues. Martin initially told MCN he was quitting road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing or road racing but has no plans to race on Hondas this year. He didn't participate in the North West 200 and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a "bloody disaster" and mentioned that the bike was not competitive. He expressed a desire to race classics and oddball events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in Nigeria's recent elections, winning 19 out of 28 governorships and marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since democracy resumed in 1999. The APC leader, Muhammadu Buhari, defeated President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential poll last month and will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost for the first time in key northern states and also lost control of Adamawa, one of the states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. The PDP managed to retain Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, but won only eight governorships mostly in the south-east. The APC made historic gains, relegating the PDP to a regional party, and won most states in the north and Lagos, the commercial hub. However, the APC did not win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for Buhari due to potential disruptions in oil production. The elections were marred by violence in some areas but were more peaceful than previous years, indicating Nigeria's democracy may be maturing. The PDP will need to rebuild under a new leader after being accused of corruption and failing to address the insurgency.

The passage discusses allegations made by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, against Olam, an agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Singapore's state-owned investment company Temasek. Mighty accuses Olam and Temasek of ignoring practices that contribute to haze in Singapore and Malaysia, which is often caused by slash-and-burn methods used by rogue palm oil traders in Indonesia. Olam and Temasek deny these allegations, asserting strict compliance policies against burning and deforestation. Olam claims it sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and has a rigorous vetting process to ensure sustainability. However, Mighty suggests Olam may be linked to unsustainable palm oil trading practices. The passage also mentions broader concerns about the palm oil industry's environmental impact, including deforestation and illegal labor practices, and highlights similar issues in Gabon where Olam is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations. Olam defends its practices in Gabon as responsible and transparent.

On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started offering "puppy platters" following a new law permitting dogs to dine in outdoor areas of restaurants. The passage highlights the novelty of this service with a reference to a video clip showcasing the unique dining experience.

The passage provides updates on the fitness of several players. Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury and has only been able to play from the bench in the last two games. Derby County striker David Nugent, who has been out with a groin injury, might return after missing the recent draw with Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hopeful for a recall after scoring a late equalizer off the bench in the same match against Huddersfield.

The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority has lifted the ban on YouTube, stating that Google's launch of a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube makes the ban unnecessary. YouTube has denied that the authorities can filter content directly. While many young Pakistanis have welcomed the decision, some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms of the agreement between Google and the government. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority confirmed that all internet service providers have been directed to restore access to YouTube. According to Pakistan's ministry of information technology, Google has provided a process for the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority to request the blocking of offending material directly. However, YouTube clarified that content removal requests would not be automatic and would adhere to their community guidelines and local legal restrictions. The ban was initially imposed in 2012 by the Supreme Court due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," which sparked protests and deaths in Pakistan. Google recently launched local versions of YouTube in Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, who shares the Swiss-Italian nationality with Gianni Infantino, one of the five candidates vying to replace Sepp Blatter as Fifa president. Scala previously excused himself from the 2015 elections due to sharing nationality with incumbent president Blatter. Musa Bility, the LFA boss, threatens to take Scala to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations which bars committee members with conflicts of interest. However, Scala's spokesman argues that shared nationality does not constitute a conflict of interest under Fifa's regulations. The election, scheduled for February 26, involves five candidates: Prince Ali of Jordan, Gianni Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman of Bahrain, and Tokyo Sexwale of South Africa. The election will be held in Zurich, Switzerland.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were tragically killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. They were likely working in a paint-spraying area when the incident occurred. Their bodies were recovered on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic investigation has been conducted at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reported "significant progress" in forensic inquiries and witness statements, indicating a flashover explosion due to a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source caused a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is also gathering evidence.

The passage provides an overview of recent events in African football, focusing on the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia nearly faced expulsion from the tournament after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) regarding a contentious penalty awarded in their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea. This led to a demand for an apology from Caf, which Tunisia eventually provided, ensuring their participation. Morocco's involvement in the 2017 Nations Cup was also uncertain after they were initially banned for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears. However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned the ban, allowing Morocco to compete. Both nations are now preparing for the tournament, with Morocco's FA chief expressing optimism about the future for both Africa and Morocco. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will play Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The passage describes a mass fracas during a football match between Chelsea and Manchester City at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1. Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho from Manchester City were sent off, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. Aguero received a four-match ban for a violent conduct charge, his second this season, after a challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz. Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban for his involvement in the ensuing scuffle. Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's part in the incident. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

In Wales and other parts of the UK, there are some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. A pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd focuses on patients whose family doctors suspect cancer but who show no urgent signs or symptoms. This initiative follows visits to Denmark where health board officials observed improved cancer survival rates. The concern is that patients in Wales without clear symptoms may wait too long for a diagnosis, not fitting easily into specific treatment pathways. This results in doctors repeatedly referring patients for multiple tests over weeks. Consequently, there is a fear that too many patients start treatment when their cancer has already progressed or is no longer curable. Forty doctors in Cwm Cynon will refer patients to a diagnostic center at Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant, within seven days, aiming to see and test around six patients weekly on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms in the Cwm Taf area receive a diagnosis. The goal is to reach the majority of patients without obvious symptoms sooner. Similar clinics will be established in Ysbyty Castell-nedd Port Talbot as part of another pilot scheme by Abertawe Bro Morgannwg Health Board. These trials were developed over the past 12 months after Welsh experts returned from Aarhus, Denmark, which established diagnostic centers due to high cancer survival rates. Dr. Gareth Davies from Cancer Wales Network believes this plan will both ease patients' minds and speed up the process. Gareth Jordan, a family doctor in Aberdâr, believes the pilot scheme could significantly impact patients' lives by ensuring quicker diagnosis if they have cancer. If successful, the six-month pilot in Cwm Cynon will lead to the same service being offered by other health boards in the area.

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, achieving their second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. The pitch offered little assistance to the bowlers, and Pakistan struggled, managing only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second. Former England players praised England's performance, while Pakistan's Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged the team's lack of confidence and poor shot selection. Pakistan will play a two-day game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on August 3.

The passage provides an overview of the British and Irish Lions' coaching setup for their tour in New Zealand. Head coach Warren Gatland has named Rob Howley as part of his backroom team, while forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time, having led Wales in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed his honor and excitement for the opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is in advanced talks to appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde during the tour and expects to finalize the management team soon. Union chairman Gareth Davies highlighted the potential benefits for Welsh rugby from having Welsh coaches involved, emphasizing the opportunity for development and inspiration from the Lions' experience.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Southampton took an early lead through Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty, but Hull City turned the game around in the second half. Hull's Robert Snodgrass, introduced from the bench after Will Keane's injury, scored a goal and assisted another for Michael Dawson. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull's David Marshall made crucial saves and Sam Clucas made a remarkable goalline clearance in the final minute to secure Hull's first league win since August 20, ending a six-game losing streak. Hull remains in the bottom three, while Southampton's focus shifts to their next matches after a European game.

A fatal crash occurred at around 14:15 BST on the B1191 road in Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. A local motorcyclist was killed, but no further details about the rider have been released. The tractor driver involved was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police are seeking witnesses to the collision and have closed the B1191 road in both directions between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle.

The passage describes President Ivanov's decision to cancel an investigation into allegations of abuse of power, which were revealed by covert recordings released in 2015. This move was condemned by both the opposition and EU officials, who argued it was illegal and not in line with the rule of law. President Ivanov claimed his actions were to "defend national interests" and to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. The opposition leader, Zoran Zaev, criticized the decision and urged protesters to gather in the capital, Skopje. The crisis was initiated by recordings that allegedly showed ministers plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder. Zaev has been releasing recordings since 2015, accusing the government of wiretapping and corruption, claims the government denies while accusing Zaev of destabilizing the nation.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Saturday's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to appoint a new boss quickly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the top choice. The club fears it may struggle to return to the Premier League if relegated, noting the increased strength of the Championship. Swansea, promoted in 2011, has faced management changes and player departures since Michael Laudrup's exit in 2014, leading to a perceived loss of the "Swansea Way." Despite this, Curtis believes the current squad has the potential to avoid relegation and emphasizes the importance of staying up for the club and the local community.

In a crucial match, Dagenham & Redbridge, needing a win to keep their survival hopes alive, faced Leyton Orient. Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, Orient's Jay Simpson and Armand Gnanduillet secured a victory that relegated Dagenham and kept Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who first reached League One in 2010, now return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously guided them to League One. The Daggers struggled defensively and offensively this season, with their goal difference being the worst in League Two. Still remains committed to promoting the team from the National League next season. Orient, now two points from play-off spots, had to cope with the recent removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan, with interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasizing professionalism and dedication to the fans.

The passage provides information about Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain, who is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February following his retirement as a player. Jurgen Klopp, Liverpool's manager, expressed his excitement about Gerrard's appointment, describing it as "wonderful news" and noting that Gerrard aspires to become a manager in the future. Klopp emphasized the importance of understanding Gerrard's ambitions and highlighted his readiness to take the necessary steps to achieve his managerial goals. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and retired after a 19-year career, had previously been linked with a managerial role at MK Dons but felt the opportunity came too soon for him. He is also pursuing his Uefa A coaching licence to qualify for managing in the Premier League.

The passage describes a football match where McManus scored twice, Ross Forbes added another goal, and Kyle McAusland briefly brought Alloa back into the game. However, goals by McManus and Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable win for the hosts.

The passage highlights that Ofsted has discovered evidence of children being taught in unsanitary conditions at three now-closed schools in Birmingham, which were operating illegally. The Chief Inspector of Schools in England, Sir Michael Wilshaw, expressed shock at the conditions and suggested that these cases may represent only a fraction of the issue. The investigation has focused on 18 unregulated schools, primarily in Muslim communities in the Midlands. The government is considering stricter regulations for places offering more than 6 to 8 hours of weekly education. Sir Michael emphasized that the issue could affect any religious group operating in unsafe conditions. The education secretary has instructed Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools, and the government is consulting on additional regulations, with a consultation deadline set for mid-January.

The passage discusses Lilliard Gin, which is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. It highlights the excitement surrounding the potential to establish the Scottish Borders' first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes emphasizes the unique scale of their gin production, which fits into a cowshed and uses one of the smallest production stills in the UK. The gin aims to capture the local flavor of the Teviot valley. John Henderson of Born in the Borders notes the gin distillery's alignment with the ethos of local sourcing and its complementary nature to the Scottish Borders Brewery. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary heroine from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, symbolizing the region's history and strong female production team.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam tragically died when Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal alcohol limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm in Rothwell, near Leeds. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. The court determined that Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law because the incident occurred on private land. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed the profound impact the accident had on their close-knit family, emphasizing the importance of not driving under the influence. The Health and Safety Executive described the incident as "extremely tragic" and deemed Green's actions as "reckless."

The passage provides an update on Luis Suarez's football activities following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). Suarez, who was previously banned from all football-related activities for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup, can now train with and play in friendly matches for his new club, Barcelona. His public presentation as a Barcelona player is scheduled for Monday at Camp Nou, though it is uncertain if he will play in that game against Mexico's Club Leon. Suarez still faces an eight-game ban for international matches and is expected to make his competitive debut for Barcelona in the El Clasico match against Real Madrid on October 26. CAS upheld FIFA's sanctions but deemed the complete ban from all football activities excessive. Suarez's lawyers argued that FIFA's punishment was too severe. Despite CAS's ruling, Suarez can participate in promotional activities and attend matches. The world players' union Fifpro expressed disappointment that CAS did not significantly reduce the sanctions, considering them disproportionate. Suarez has a history of disciplinary issues, including previous suspensions for biting opponents and racial abuse.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a challenging 380-metre race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved running around an athletics track, hurdling haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. Despite the tough competition, especially from the Lithuanians, Rich and Anna's week of training paid off. The event allowed various combinations of participants, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and even a woman carrying another woman. As winners, Rich and Anna will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond, in response to concerns raised by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, assured that job roles at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) would change but not through job losses when the paper car tax disc system is replaced with an electronic system in October. Hammond explained that the new direct debit payment system might reduce the need for certain roles, necessitating training for new processes. He assured that any reductions would be managed by redeploying staff to other growing areas within the business. Hedges expressed relief over the commitment to redeployment rather than redundancies and believed this response would reassure concerned DVLA employees.

The passage discusses Hungary's stance on EU interference in its domestic policies, particularly regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education laws. Hungary's Foreign Minister, Mr. Szijjarto, asserts that these issues fall under national competence and should not be interfered with by the EU. He mentions Poland's support in vetoing any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU is critical of Hungary's strict asylum controls, a higher education law that could close the Central European University (CEU), and pending NGO legislation. Despite pressure from European institutions, Hungary remains firm on its laws, with protests against these laws occurring in the country. The EU has threatened action if no positive changes occur soon.

The passage provides details about the cast and release date of an upcoming live-action adaptation of the animated film. The star will voice Mrs. Potts, the magically transformed teapot originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson, known for her role in Harry Potter, is cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens from Downton Abbey as the Beast and Luke Evans as the villain Gaston. Josh Gad, famous for voicing Olaf in Frozen, will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set to release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, and will begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist for the Sunday Times, passed away after a battle with multiple cancers, which he humorously referred to as "the full English of cancers." Despite undergoing chemotherapy, Gill maintained a positive outlook and considered himself fortunate in life. Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens praised Gill as "a giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Gill's final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, will be published posthumously. Known for his controversial yet brilliant writing, Gill was also recognized for his wit and compassion. His career spanned decades, starting with art reviews and continuing through various publications, including the Sunday Times, where he became a beloved figure. Gill's life was marked by both professional achievements and personal challenges, including overcoming dyslexia and navigating several high-profile relationships.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator by a Russian diplomatic officer. The incident occurred while Sukhbaatar was performing in a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a symbol that predates the Nazis but is associated with them. Sukhbaatar was reportedly hit over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face, resulting in a serious brain injury that left him in a coma for about 10 days. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but claims local press reports are "distorted." Sukhbaatar's lawyer and family deny claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the performance. The suspect has not been arrested, though Mongolian authorities insist he should be investigated under Mongolian law regardless of his diplomatic status.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a protest against the airport's expansion plans on Monday, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a restricted aerodrome area. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. The Metropolitan Police announced a review of airport security and the campaigners are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August.

In a cricket match, Glamorgan's total was led by Nick Selman's century, his second first-class hundred, which came off 144 balls. However, Gloucestershire's bowlers, particularly Matt Taylor and Craig Miles, ensured wickets fell regularly. Gloucestershire struggled throughout the day as Glamorgan's bowlers dominated. Selman's century was a welcome return to form after a series of low scores. Aneurin Donald's quick 36 was the next best contribution for Glamorgan. Despite efforts by Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten, Gloucestershire's innings was a struggle, ending the day evenly balanced. Glamorgan is now being led by Michael Hogan due to Jacques Rudolph's neck injury. The match ended with the score evenly poised, setting up a challenging day for Gloucestershire's batsmen.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he communicated online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, planning to ambush police officers by making a false report of a crime. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and is awaiting sentencing. He had previously been convicted for possessing a firearm in 2009. The threats were made while Hughes was drunk on two occasions late at night. Despite his legal team's claims that he had no intention of killing himself or officers, North Wales Police were concerned due to his bail status for firearms offences. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to those in crisis.

The passage describes a cricket match where Surrey posted a strong score of 255-7, with Chris Davies and Ben Foakes forming a crucial partnership of 130 runs. Yorkshire's run-chase was hampered by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, who took three wickets in nine balls, including those of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan scored 68 but was the last man out as Yorkshire were all out for 236. Despite a promising start, Yorkshire couldn't maintain their momentum due to Meaker's spell and failed to reach the target. Surrey's Gareth Batty praised the team's performance, while Yorkshire's Alex Lees expressed disappointment, noting the team's exceptional bowling but lack of support from the middle order.

A 56ft converted trawler experienced water ingress 6 miles west of South Stack and contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST. The Holyhead coastguards reported that a pump on board was insufficient. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

The passage discusses Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir's decision to miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, explains that her exams in May make it impossible to participate in the April Commonwealth Games. Despite her disappointment, she emphasizes the importance of completing her degree and looks forward to future Olympic opportunities. Muir also mentions the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target and expresses her satisfaction with her recent performance, highlighting her new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m race.

Robbie Savage's BBC Sport column discusses Liverpool's prospects for the season, focusing on their inability to replicate last year's title challenge. He highlights the team's struggles in scoring, particularly after the departures of Luis Suarez and the injury to Daniel Sturridge, and criticizes Brendan Rodgers' transfer decisions in the attacking positions. Liverpool's defensive issues persist despite significant spending. Savage also examines Steven Gerrard's physical and mental challenges in maintaining his performance at age 34, emphasizing his importance to the team despite past setbacks. Savage concludes that Liverpool will need significant improvement to compete against Chelsea, who remain dominant in the Premier League.

The passage describes a £45m educational facility to be constructed at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus in honor of the late William McIlvanney, a renowned writer from Kilmarnock known for his contributions to literature, including the Laidlaw trilogy, and his passion for education. McIlvanney, who passed away on December 5, was also a respected poet, journalist, broadcaster, and an influential figure in Scottish political and sporting life.

The town area near the swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to the discovery of a sea mine, believed to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s. Three streets were evacuated, and residents within 500 meters were advised to stay indoors. An exclusion zone was also in place on the river and at sea, with small boat owners cautioned against sailing. Ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay experienced some disruption. The evacuation was precautionary, with no immediate danger, according to Ch Insp Elliot Brown. Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis noted the mine's deterioration made it uncertain how much explosive material it still contained, prompting its relocation for safe handling. Inverclyde Council thanked Gourock residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation and cordon procedures.

The passage discusses funding decisions made by UK Sport for Team GB's sports ahead of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics. Despite Team GB's success in Rio 2016, funding has been cut for several sports, including cycling, which saw a reduction of over £4m to £25.98m. Notably, badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio, had its funding completely removed, a decision that has been criticized by Badminton England. Overall, £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, £2 less than the previous record. UK Sport has set a target for Team GB to win between 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. The funding decisions aim to prioritize sports with the highest medal potential to maintain historic success. Some sports, like judo, saw slight increases in funding, while others, including basketball, handball, and volleyball, lost funding previously. UK Sport is yet to confirm investment for five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020, with £9m of the total funding still unallocated.

A six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks are set to replace three Victorian hotels in East Cliff, Bournemouth. Despite strong objections from English Heritage regarding the scale of the development in a designated conservation area, councillors voted seven to three in favor, citing benefits to tourism. The project, proposed by The East Cliff Project LLP, will see the demolition of Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels to make way for a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. While 246 letters supported the plans, 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, emphasizing the historic character of the existing buildings. English Heritage warned that the development would cause "severe harm" to the conservation area.

The passage details the tragic incident where Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked in Brecon. Off-duty and returning to his barracks after training exercises, Boyd was punched and beaten by Jake Vallely outside a bar. Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge, dragged Boyd's unconscious body away before fleeing. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Vallely will be sentenced on December 8. The community of Brecon was deeply shocked by the "despicable act," and a family tribute remembered Pte Boyd as a loving, caring, and loyal individual with a promising future, whose life was cut short by Vallely's violence. The tribute highlighted the community's support for the Boyd family, asserting that those who showed love and support were the true "strongest people in Brecon."

Andrew Travers left his position as chief executive of Barnet Council following an incident where voters were turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the electoral registration lists. An independent investigation has been launched to address the issue. Travers expressed his belief in the borough's future success and was praised for his contributions during his tenure. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over while longer-term arrangements are made. The council apologized for the problems and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. The council's review, set to conclude by the end of May, will examine the arrangements for the EU Referendum and will be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee.

In a closely contested match, Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies opened the scoring for Gateshead with a fine free-kick, but Wrexham equalized before halftime through Sean Newton's set-piece. Gateshead's Ryan Bowman secured the win with a header from Craig Baxter's cross in the second half. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's performance, especially the improved passing in the second half. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment, noting his team's missed opportunities and defensive lapses in the second half. The final score was Gateshead 2, Wrexham 1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan and Mozambique rank lowest.

The passage outlines the ambitious OneWeb project, a collaboration between Airbus and OneWeb, to create a vast network of at least 600, potentially over 2,000, satellites to provide global broadband coverage, especially targeting schools. To achieve this, they are adopting high-volume, low-cost manufacturing methods similar to car and plane production, aiming to produce three satellites per shift for under a million dollars each. This shift requires a significant change in traditional satellite manufacturing, which is costly and time-consuming. The first assembly line has been established in Toulouse, France, with two more planned in Florida. The project plans to launch the first 10 satellites in April next year, followed by more in November and a rapid cadence thereafter. To establish the constellation, over 20 Soyuz rockets will be used. The project faces competition from other companies like SpaceX and Boeing but claims a first-mover advantage. It has secured $1.7 billion in equity and is working on securing loans. The UK, where OneWeb is registered, will play a significant role due to its regulatory oversight and economic ties. There is concern about space debris, but OneWeb has committed to de-orbiting satellites within two years and has implemented measures to mitigate debris risks. The new manufacturing methods may disrupt traditional satellite industry practices, though not all satellites will require such high volumes.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Mr. Swinney criticized the UK government's recent spending review, stating it places "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland. Despite the UK government claiming Scottish ministers will have £390m more spending available next year, Swinney argues that since 2010, Scottish discretionary budget cuts will be 12.5% lower by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with 4.2% of these cuts occurring before 2020. Swinney emphasized that the UK government's austerity measures will leave Scotland with tough choices but vowed to protect key services like schools, hospitals, and the police. In response, the UK government's Scotland Office highlighted the additional £390m available to Scotland next year and suggested the Scottish government focus on its new powers rather than grievances. Labour's Jackie Baillie urged Swinney to present a long-term budget and criticized the Scottish government for focusing on spin rather than its record.

The passage highlights the challenges faced by families with severely disabled members due to the lack of accessible Changing Places toilets in public spaces. These specialized toilets, which offer more space and enhanced facilities, are crucial for individuals who require significant assistance to use standard accessible toilets. Although there are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, many families still struggle to find suitable facilities, leading to feelings of isolation and stress. Lorna Fillingham, a mother advocating for better accessibility, has started a petition and provided evidence to a parliamentary committee to push for compulsory Changing Places guidelines in building regulations. While Changing Places specifications have been recommended since 2009, they are not mandatory, causing many to be overlooked in new constructions. Campaigners are urging for these to become compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers and sports stadiums due to the logistical and financial barriers faced by existing businesses. The passage also notes positive examples, such as Arsenal Football Club's successful installation of a Changing Places toilet, which has been well-received by both fans and the public.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's responded by stating that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, claiming this approach has been successful for many years. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and several European unions support the complaint, arguing that McDonald's abuse of its dominant market position harms franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will study the complaint and may launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed valid. The consumer organisations also claim that McDonald's prevents franchisees from switching to competitors by making them sign longer contracts and lease premises at above-market rates, which allegedly leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to company-owned outlets. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe.

The passage describes a social media campaign initiated by Bangor Elim Church to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign, featuring the hashtag #prayforjosh, began on Facebook and Instagram and quickly went viral, garnering global support. The hashtag was started by the church where Josh's father works, and it has been shared widely, reaching over 79,000 people. Additionally, a massive billboard with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood, funded by an anonymous donor. The campaign has received widespread support from people worldwide, including Josh's classmates on Twitter. The church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, expressed amazement at the level of support and gratitude for the billboard's appearance.

The passage discusses a military restructuring in the UK that includes the closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic site in Brecon that has been in operation since 1805. Conservative MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the closure, highlighting the barracks' distinguished service in every conflict since the early 19th century and expressing concern over the impact on local unemployment and military tourism. The Defence Secretary, Sir Michael Fallon, announced the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan and confirmed the closures of Cawdor Barracks and a storage depot at Sennybridge. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary, Nia Griffith, acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned of the uncertainty it would bring to those affected.

The passage discusses the potential risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry following Brexit. It highlights that while many in the fishing community view Brexit as a chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish exporter, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns that these communities risk being marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized by the industry, but it ensures equal access to fishing grounds, which is crucial for the UK industry's continued market access. The Lords report suggests that the UK may need to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a Brexit deal to maintain market access. The report also emphasizes the need to retain elements of the CFP and to base quotas on scientific advice. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the opportunities Brexit could bring, such as control over the 200-mile exclusive economic zone and better sustainable fisheries management. The government aims to ensure maximum trading freedom while reviewing fisheries management for fair access and sustainable stocks.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks that exposed extensive US surveillance activities. US Director of National Intelligence James Clapper deemed these leaks as "extremely damaging" to national security, while Snowden argued he acted due to his horror at the surveillance extent. The US National Security Agency (NSA) had access to vast amounts of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, and social networking information. The NSA confirmed requesting millions of phone records from Verizon, including call details. Prism, a surveillance program, allegedly enabled "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies, though these companies denied involvement. NSA Director Keith Alexander claimed these operations kept Americans safe but couldn't provide details. Data protection laws in different countries regulate company data handling but don't directly address government surveillance. US President Barack Obama defended surveillance tactics, emphasizing security over privacy. The US Patriot Act and FISA Act facilitated US access to foreign data stored in the US. The involvement of other governments, like the UK's GCHQ, remains unclear. The EU expressed concern over the impact on EU citizens. Despite assurances from UK Foreign Secretary William Hague that law-abiding citizens have nothing to fear, Privacy International highlighted global privacy violations through the Prism program. Snowden's motivation stemmed from his opposition to pervasive surveillance.

The passage discusses the backing of Open AI, a research venture that includes prominent investors such as Tesla Motors and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, Paypal co-founder Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. Open AI aims to conduct research free from financial obligations, focusing on achieving a "positive human impact" with its advancements in artificial intelligence (AI). There is a noted concern among scientists, including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, that AI could pose an existential threat to humanity. However, the venture emphasizes its mission to advance digital intelligence in a manner that benefits all of humanity, without the pressure to generate financial returns. Open AI aims for AI to be an extension of human wills, distributed as broadly and evenly as possible while ensuring safety. Only a small portion of the $1 billion pledged will be spent in the initial years.

The passage describes the story of L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Despite the brain injury that affected his speech, he has retained his personality, sense of humor, intelligence, and wit. After carrying the Olympic torch on 26 June, he received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the platform limits personal pages to 5,000 friend associations. Despite this limitation, he has been surrounded by hundreds of supporters and has walked with the Olympic torch for nearly half an hour. L/Bdr Parkinson spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and the rest of his time raising money for military charities and supporting his beloved Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, expressed amazement at the overwhelming support and the phenomenal response they have received, including 19,000 hits on an update page. Facebook suggested that he could either create a public page or use a subscription model to manage the influx of requests. Overall, L/Bdr Parkinson's journey has inspired many, and he is described as "buoyed up" and "elated" by the support.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US was 15%, which remained unchanged after three years of increases. This equated to 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of uninsured Americans dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%. Notably, poverty reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

The passage provides information about Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer who moved to Lancashire (referred to as the Red Rose) from Somerset in 2013. He has signed a new deal that will keep him with the club until 2019. Buttler is recognized as a short-format specialist and holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a remarkable 46-ball century against Pakistan. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent and his contribution to the team's victory in last year's T20 Blast final. Buttler, who has also played in the Indian Premier League for Mumbai Indians, is set to return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to express interest in purchasing these former Devonport-based ships. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted, but interested parties are finalizing their bids with viewings scheduled for late February and March. A final decision on the sale is expected in the spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports this while also advocating for at least one ship to be saved for a reef or diving attraction to benefit tourism. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers. The Type 22 frigates were originally designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful surface combatants. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3m.

The passage describes the political and racial tensions in Fiji since 1987, which have led to instability and international isolation. Key events include a 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians that overthrew an Indian-dominated coalition, a 2000 coup led by George Speight that held the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister hostage, and a 2006 military takeover. These events severely damaged Fiji's economy and international reputation. In 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth due to its lack of democratic progress. However, after agreeing to hold free elections in 2014, diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand were restored, and Fiji was re-instated into the Commonwealth. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the latter group historically being a significant minority but many having fled due to political unrest. Fiji's economy, while diverse, relies heavily on sugar and tourism and is one of the largest per capita recipients of aid due to persistent trade and budget deficits.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is making its best efforts to comply with the UN-backed timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Mekdad cited security issues, including attacks on shipments, as reasons for the delays. He defended the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, accusing the US of supporting terrorist groups in Syria. The Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, while the Observatory claimed that the prison had been taken over by rebel forces. Only about 4% of Syria's declared chemical weapons stockpile has left the country so far, according to the US, raising concerns about the plan's adherence to the June deadline for complete destruction. Russia, a key ally of Syria, urged Damascus to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by 1 March. Mekdad reaffirmed Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The passage provides a summary of the Booker Prize shortlist for the 46th year of the award, which is now open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" is the favorite to win, followed by Richard Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North" at 3/1. The shortlist includes Howard Jacobson for his novel "J," Ali Smith for "How To Be Both," Joshua Ferris for "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour," Karen Joy Fowler for "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves," and Richard Flanagan for "The Narrow Road to the Deep North." The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, with the ceremony broadcast on the BBC News Channel and BBC Arts. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling and includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven, and Erica Wagner. Last year's winner was Eleanor Catton for "The Luminaries."

The passage details a legal battle over the privacy of a celebrity referred to as PJS, who is appealing against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will now consider whether to grant PJS's appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the Supreme Court hearing. PJS argues for his right to privacy, especially given his young children and spouse's public profile. The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish details of PJS's alleged extra-marital activities, which include a three-way encounter with two other individuals. Despite a High Court refusal to impose an injunction initially, PJS successfully appealed, leading to the current legal situation.
