The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22, will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews from festival signs and posters. Headliners this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlights the app as an additional feature to enhance the festival experience, enabling global interaction and capturing the festival's atmosphere. The app will provide instant access to information, interviews, ticket purchases, and festival updates.

The passage outlines the decision to terminate the funding agreements for Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned of potential funding loss unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher from one of the Trojan Horse schools revealed parents' interference during an Ofsted inspection and their attempts to undermine her authority. The watchdog published reports on 21 schools allegedly targeted in a hardline Muslim takeover, with five, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate. Education minister Lord Nash criticized the trusts for failing to promote pupils' spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development and outlined specific actions required to avoid funding termination. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw highlighted a culture of fear and intimidation in Birmingham schools. The report into Park View School noted inadequate work to keep students safe from extremism, including improper vetting of external speakers. Parents criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and pushing their own agendas.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 after an eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court accused eye specialist Honey Rose of conduct that was "criminally" below the expected standard. Rose allegedly failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the routine test and did not refer him for further investigation. This failure led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution claims Vinnie's death was preventable if Rose had performed her duties properly. Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg arranged meetings between a woman and a man he found on an adult website, during which he filmed their sexual activities. He was found guilty of coercing the woman into having sex with the man between September 2013 and September 2014. Weatherhogg also sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. He was convicted and placed on the sex offenders register. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. The woman testified that she felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg. The judge emphasized the need for a sentence that reflects society's abhorrence of such conduct, noting Weatherhogg's moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

In a T20 cricket match in Greater Noida, Ireland made 165-5 with Stuart Thompson scoring 56, Gary Wilson remaining unbeaten on 41, and William Porterfield contributing 39. Afghanistan successfully chased the target, finishing at 171-4 with Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad playing crucial roles. Ireland's Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck early on, but Thompson and Porterfield steadied the innings. Afghanistan's Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai set a strong foundation with a 51-run opening stand. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2 wickets, while the batting dominated the game. Ireland's captain Porterfield acknowledged they could have scored more and expressed disappointment with their bowling performance. Additionally, Ireland faced a setback with paceman Boyd Rankin being ruled out due to a back injury, although he is expected to return for the upcoming five ODIs against Afghanistan starting on 15 March.

The passage discusses the financial and legal issues surrounding FC Barcelona's signing of Neymar from Santos. The club insists they have not committed any offense and have made a voluntary tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential interpretations of tax obligations related to the transfer. The total cost to Barcelona for Neymar, including various fees, amounts to £106.8m. The club denies any tax-related crime and maintains that the original tax payment complied with fiscal obligations. The case against Barcelona is ongoing, and it is unclear if the payment will result in the case being dropped. Neymar has performed well for Barcelona, scoring 10 goals in 25 appearances this season.

The passage provides a summary of the investigation into the murders of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, whose bodies were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK Metropolitan Police officers collaborated with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, who allegedly confessed to the crimes. The UK detectives have completed their work in Thailand and will return to compile a report and update the victims' families. The suspects face charges of conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, potentially leading to the death penalty. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA verification and allegations of suspect mistreatment. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police claim DNA evidence from the suspects matches that found on Witheridge.

The Scots have won all five of their qualifiers and are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with a victory likely securing their place in the finals. Captain Evans is determined to avoid past heartbreak from play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the World Cup. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland, is also unbeaten and the outcome of the upcoming matches will likely determine the group's top spot. Evans emphasizes the importance of reaching the finals, a goal she has held since joining the squad, and notes the significance of having fans support them. Many players in the squad, including Evans, play in top leagues abroad, which she believes enhances the national team's competitiveness and adds a different playing style and culture.

The passage discusses the implementation of a two-step verification system by Apple to enhance the security of iCloud accounts, following reports that third-party software had been used to steal intimate photos of celebrities. This new security measure requires an extra step after entering a username and password on an unfamiliar device, including a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases is blocked, though a 14-character recovery key can be used if the trusted device is lost. Previously, even with two-step verification enabled, attackers could still download iCloud backups using Elcomsoft's software. However, Apple's recent changes are said to guard against this technique. While the ElcomSoft owner acknowledges the effectiveness of the new system, he raises concerns about the recovery key's memorability and security. An expert suggests that two-factor authentication should be the default setting, not an opt-in choice. Apple plans to encourage users to adopt stronger passwords and two-factor authentication more aggressively.

The passage provides details on the campaign expenditures of several UK political parties during the election period from January 23 to May 22. UKIP, which won the election, spent £2,956,737, while the Tories spent £2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) spent £1,580,575 but lost all but one of their MEPs. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. The Green Party spent £534,249, and the SNP spent £267,372. The total campaign spending of the six highest-spending parties amounted to £9,347,087, with all but Labour spending more than in the 2009 European election. The cost per vote for these parties varied, with UKIP at 68p, Conservatives at 79p, Labour at 26p, Lib Dems at £1.45, Greens at 43p, and SNP not specified in per vote terms.

Centre-back Anderson, aged 27, has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow to join their National League opponents. The former Aldershot and Exeter player, who has also played in Italy, might face his old team on February 18. Striker Keating, 21, recommended to Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His transfer is pending international clearance. Nicholson praised Anderson as a leader with stature and experience. Keating is described as young and eager to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six matches.

The passage describes the tragic death of a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds after he won the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite narrowly beating Thistlecrack, Many Clouds collapsed and was later pronounced dead by veterinary staff. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, noted that such episodes are rare and can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, including overheating and wobbling, but had not collapsed before and showed no such symptoms after the race. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described Many Clouds as the "horse of a lifetime," having previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Despite previous treatment for overheating, the report concludes that Many Clouds died from a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack.

The passage describes emotional farewells from several veteran MSPs ahead of the upcoming election on May 5. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly moved by speeches from Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond. McNeil, who has served since the parliament's inception in 1999, emphasized the importance of accountability and scrutiny in Holyrood. Salmond, the former first minister, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse but not divided, and highlighted the progress made in Scottish governance. He also expressed disappointment that the Scotland Bill did not fully meet unionist promises. Salmond concluded with a heartfelt farewell, while Marwick praised Salmond's distinguished service. Annabel Goldie, a former Conservative MSP, also joked about her departure, particularly missing interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage provides details about the cast and release of a live-action adaptation of the animated film "Beauty and the Beast." The star will voice Mrs. Potts, the magically transformed teapot originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson, known for her role in Harry Potter, is cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens from "Downton Abbey" as the Beast and Luke Evans as the villain Gaston. Josh Gad, famous for voicing Olaf in "Frozen," will play LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set for release on March 17, 2017, and filming will start in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will inform relatives of the 96 football fans who died in the 1989 Hillsborough disaster about potential charges against 23 suspects at a meeting in Warrington at 11:00 BST. Last year, new inquests concluded that the fans were unlawfully killed. The CPS will decide whether to bring charges based on evidence from two investigations: 15 related to the causes of the disaster and 8 related to police conduct. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall, whose son died, have endured a long wait for these decisions and hope it marks the end of their struggle for accountability.

The passage highlights several issues surrounding Chelmsford Prison, including "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over the prison wall, with one former inmate claiming the jail is notorious for receiving mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the hard work of staff in preventing contraband entry but admits more needs to be done. The Justice Secretary has requested further examination into equipping prisons with better tools to tackle this problem. A local resident reported witnessing such packages being thrown over the wall multiple times in a short period. While the Ministry of Justice denies evidence of drones being used to deliver contraband to the prison, laws have been introduced to impose up to two years in jail for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, sustained serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The incident occurred when Mrs. Blackburn was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road as traffic lights turned red. Wright's VW Golf failed to stop, hitting Mrs. Blackburn. She is now in residential care. The trial is ongoing, with Wright expressing remorse for the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family.

The passage discusses Scottish middle distance runner Muir, who has to miss the Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Despite finishing fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, she cites her exams in May as the reason she cannot participate in the April event. Muir expresses her disappointment but emphasizes the importance of her degree and looks forward to future Olympic opportunities. She also mentions the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target and highlights her new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m race, expressing satisfaction with her performance and potential for the future.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. A search in Chapelizod, Dublin, began early Saturday morning, focusing on a three-acre woodland area near the River Liffey. The search, expected to last several weeks, involves excavations. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed Deely's disappearance, enhancing CCTV footage showing him talking to a man in black outside his workplace. The man was also seen following Deely shortly after. Despite releasing the footage in April and appealing for information, the man has not been identified.

Juan Del Potro secured a hard-fought victory over Swiss player Stan Wawrinka in the second round of a Grand Slam tournament, winning 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3. Del Potro, who is ranked 165th due to a long injury layoff, fought back from an early deficit to win the match. He will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro expressed his joy at returning to competitive play after multiple wrist surgeries. In other matches, Nick Kyrgios advanced to the third round, and Feliciano Lopez defeated Fabio Fognini to set up a match with Kyrgios. Additionally, Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga secured routine victories in their respective matches.

The passage provides an overview of the football events involving Tunisia and Morocco in the context of the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON). Tunisia nearly faced expulsion from the 2017 AFCON due to complaints against the tournament's organization but resolved the issue by apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (CAF). Morocco's participation in the 2017 AFCON was initially banned but overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). Morocco had previously been penalized for refusing to host the 2015 AFCON due to Ebola fears, but CAS reduced the fine. Tunisia's participation was secured after resolving disputes with CAF. Both teams are preparing for the 2017 AFCON, with Tunisia aiming for their first title since 2004. The passage also mentions the contentious penalty incident in the 2015 quarter-final that led to Tunisia's complaints.

The passage provides a detailed history of McLaren, highlighting its past successes and current struggles. Once a dominant force in Formula 1, McLaren has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles. However, the team has fallen on hard times, with recent results placing them in the fourth row of the grid. The decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and despite improvements in the car, the Honda power unit continues to be problematic. McLaren's illustrious history includes notable successes with drivers like Ayrton Senna, Alain Prost, Mika Hakkinen, and Lewis Hamilton. The team's recent troubles include scandals and a loss of dominance, but team principal Ron Dennis remains optimistic about a return to success, citing the potential of current drivers, including Fernando Alonso, and the renewed partnership with Honda. Dennis believes that McLaren will eventually break Mercedes' dominance and reclaim its former glory.

In October 2014, paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where police later found several patrons still present. Alcohol service continued until 04:49 BST, prompting charges against Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas for allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, criticized the poor adherence to licensing laws, and highlighted O'Neill's "appalling record." O'Neill, the license holder, was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, making eight to surpass his previous record of 272 set two years ago. He scored 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit six 3-pointers before halftime and teamed with Klay Thompson to help the Warriors overcome a 13-point deficit. The Blazers' LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 points, and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists. In another game, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol contributing 16 points and 15 rebounds, and Derrick Rose scoring 12 points as the Bulls made a remarkable comeback from a 19-point halftime deficit.

The passage describes an encounter between Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic and YouTube star Bas van Velzen at Melwood. Initially, the players were led to believe that van Velzen was a competition winner who had won a chance to meet them and receive a dead-ball masterclass. However, van Velzen, a Dutch free-kick specialist, quickly demonstrated his impressive skills, surprising the Liverpool players. Van Velzen's free-kicks left the players in awe, and Balotelli eventually executed a perfectly-executed free-kick himself. Van Velzen, known for his YouTube videos showcasing his free-kick talents, expressed his enjoyment of the experience and the satisfaction of seeing the players' reactions to his skills. He also had a final surprise for Balotelli, referencing his infamous slogan from a past match.

The passage discusses how women who carry the BRCA1 gene, such as Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by undergoing an oophorectomy, a procedure to remove the ovaries. The study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, finding that those who had oophorectomies had a 62% reduction in breast cancer death and a 65% reduction in death from all causes. For BRCA1 carriers who had their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis, the reduction in death was 73%. The study suggests that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer. The protective effect of the procedure was evident immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The passage also notes that women with a significant family history of breast cancer may have an increased risk of developing the disease, and that BRCA gene faults are more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Jolie, who had both an oophorectomy and a double mastectomy due to her BRCA1 mutation, emphasized that the procedures did not diminish her sense of femininity.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were killed when an Amtrak train struck them on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina. The accident occurred shortly before 10 am as they lingered on the tracks. The train, Amtrak's Carolinian (Train No. 80), was en route from Charlotte to New York City and was on property owned by Norfolk Southern when the incident happened. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, though a man fell ill during the delay and received treatment. The train resumed its journey after a delay of about two and a half hours. A man who knew the couple mentioned they might have lived in a homeless camp and often asked for help. Durham is approximately 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, the train's next destination. The typical journey from Charlotte to New York City takes around 13 hours and 30 minutes.

The passage details the story of Carlos Toro, a former member of the Medellín Cartel who became an undercover operative for the DEA in exchange for the promise of U.S. citizenship. After fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss, Toro provided valuable information to the DEA about his former associates, becoming one of its most important assets and aiding in global undercover operations. Despite his significant contributions, including helping to prosecute notorious drug lords like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, Toro is now facing deportation after retiring due to declining health. The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship, leaving him in legal limbo and fearing for his life if returned to Colombia. Toro's former handler and colleagues have expressed support for his case, but he remains in uncertainty.

The passage discusses the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for its use of the new ".sucks" domain name. This domain is being used to extort high fees from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo, which are paying to remove their names from these domains to protect their reputations. ICANN initially approved the ".sucks" domain but is now reconsidering after complaints from an advisory panel that includes Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay, labeling it a "shakedown scheme." Vox Populi has recommended charging $2,499 per year for these domains, with resellers selling them for around $2,000 annually. ICANN has contacted U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, and if so, it may seek to change the company's behavior or take other actions under their agreement.

The passage describes the resolution of a 27-year-old mystery surrounding the death of a baby boy whose body was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. The mother, who concealed her pregnancy and delivered the baby stillborn in 1988, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained the circumstances. Advances in DNA technology led police to identify her through a national database. The baby was reburied with a headstone named Peter after the local church. Police ruled out foul play and the mother remains on bail pending a decision on charges related to failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The case highlights the persistence of police in solving long-standing mysteries.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to his passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving taxi. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to avoid paying the fare and drove him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving for almost a mile, causing Hicks to jump out at over 20mph, resulting in devastating injuries. At the High Court, Mr Justice Edis ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The exact amount of compensation, expected to be around 50% of the family's request, is yet to be determined. Hicks now requires round-the-clock care and has developed epilepsy and other health issues. Both parties have the right to appeal, and a further hearing will decide the final compensation amount.

On Wednesday night, Kansas experienced tornado sirens as several storms brought reports of twisters. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, which is less than 15 miles west of Wichita. This storm moved northeast, missing Wichita but posing risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado sightings occurred near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. Additionally, Missouri's Potosi may have experienced a tornado, with reports of wind damage and flooding. Aerial footage showed damage to roofs and water-covered streets. More storms are expected on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

The passage provides a preview of an upcoming middleweight fight between Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida in New Jersey. Rockhold aims to dominate Machida by playing the "bull" to Machida's "matador," cutting off his opponent's running style and exploiting perceived weaknesses. Rockhold believes he has a significant advantage both on the feet and on the ground, while Machida thinks he can win by applying his own fighting style and technique. Both fighters respect each other but are focused on securing victory. Rockhold is coming off a win against Michael Bisping, and Machida recently defeated CB Dollaway. The winner of their fight is expected to earn a title shot.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft made a startling belly landing at Aero Acres Residential Airpark. The plane, an Aerostar, touched down without deploying its landing gear, causing its propellers to ricochet off the runway and the wings to bounce. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to regain control and take off, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely. The incident, captured on video, has prompted an investigation by the FAA. The most common causes of such gear-up landings are human error or mechanical faults.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but has vowed to support him until the end of the season. Despite criticism of Toure's contributions amid City's poor campaign, Pellegrini insists Toure does not need a break and remains an important player. City is open to offers for Toure in the summer as they aim to overhaul their aging squad. The team faces challenges, including the absence of captain Vincent Kompany due to injury. Goalkeeper Joe Hart emphasized the players' responsibility for the team's performance. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has cautioned left-back Aaron Cresswell against joining City, warning him of limited playing time and financial implications.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the godfather of Uxbridge, will remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence from a 1999 Italian court was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was arrested in 2013 under a European arrest warrant but lost his extradition battle in February. However, his case expired in October, and his European arrest warrant is now to be withdrawn. Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished if more than double the penalty's time has passed. Although his conviction remains, Rancadore's lawyers are confident he will be discharged. The case will still need to be reviewed by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore, who was never convicted of murder but was found guilty of mafia association, can now live in peace in England with his family.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, ridden by Nico de Boinville. AP McCoy and Mr. Mole will face six rivals in the race, marking McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. His final rides for his last day as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday morning. Notably, McCoy announced his retirement after riding Mr. Mole to victory in February. Other competitors in the race include Mick Channon's Somersby.

The passage recounts the tragic story of Marcia Trimble Ritter, who was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Her mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, initially avoided seeing crime scene photos of her daughter's body at the advice of her then-husband, who wanted their last memory of Marcia to be of her alive. However, decades later, Ritter decided to see the photos, expressing regret for not viewing them sooner. After viewing the graphic photos, Ritter expressed a desire for revenge against Barrett, who was convicted of Marcia's murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The passage also mentions that Marcia's body was found in a garage near her home, and the case remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett's DNA matched evidence from the crime scene.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters to complete the career grand slam. He considers his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta National to be the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons. McIlroy aims to claim his first Green Jacket and join the elite group of golfers who have won all four major titles: Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. Despite only having one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy is determined to achieve this career-long goal. He reflects on his past successes, including bouncing back from the 2011 collapse to win the US Open, and hopes to emulate Jack Nicklaus by winning all four majors. McIlroy sees the Masters as a sanctuary from the pressures surrounding the tournament and is focused on playing his best to secure a victory.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

This week saw several trending stories online. Highlights include four rainbows appearing in the New York sky after heavy rain, a fashion CEO capturing the moment. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers at wakes is becoming common but is now targeted by a vice crackdown. RDJ became agitated during a UK interview about his private life. A new trend, the #kyliejennerchallenge, involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar. A 102-year-old woman traveled back in time with filmmakers' help. A controversial prom-posal accused school administrators of racism. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," and Johnny Depp's transformation in "Black Mass" has drawn attention. A creative pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombed his son's photo, earning praise for originality. All these stories trended this week.

The passage highlights the alarming rise in hospitalizations of children born with foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) due to their mothers' alcohol consumption during pregnancy. According to the official health and social care information centre, 272 youngsters were hospitalized in England over the past year with FAS. However, experts warn that the actual number could be much higher. Research by the World Health Organisation suggests that at least one in 100 babies in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioural, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 babies annually. The passage also mentions the case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who was diagnosed with FAS at age five and faces significant developmental challenges. The government advises pregnant women not to drink alcohol, recommending a maximum of two units no more than twice a week, but some experts, like Elizabeth Mitchell, argue that women should be advised to abstain from alcohol entirely during pregnancy.

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, was jailed after attempting to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham. The robbery was thwarted when the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerry, and his wife, Sam, hit him with a baseball bat. McKerry, previously known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" due to his history of returning home after crimes, pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in prison. He had a long criminal history starting from shoplifting at age 12, with over 80 arrests by the age of 15.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley—charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party in a Canadian barracks must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. They appeared in a Dartmouth courtroom, where they were given bail conditions requiring them to live at the Stadanoca naval base in Halifax, surrender their passports, and not contact the victim or six witnesses. Bail was set at over £2,000 each, and they will continue to work for the Royal Navy. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after a hockey game. The accused must not leave Nova Scotia, cannot apply for new passports, and must remain employed by the navy without resigning without court permission. The case is still under investigation, with potential for additional charges based on forensic results.

The passage describes the harrowing experience of Valerie Jackson, whose four-year-old son RJ suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an incredibly rare congenital skin disease that causes his skin to appear red and scaly. Valerie has to regularly apply creams to RJ's skin to prevent it from drying out. While shopping, Valerie was surrounded by armed police after a stranger mistook RJ's condition for signs of abuse, leading to a false report to the police. Valerie expressed frustration over the public's ignorance and the cruel taunts RJ and she face from others, including being denied entry to play centers and receiving hurtful comments. Despite the challenges, Valerie sees RJ as a beautiful and bubbly boy and hopes that as he grows, more people will understand his condition.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" campaign featuring bikini-clad model Renee Somerfield on London Underground posters. The campaign sparked outrage among feminists and body image campaigners, leading to over 50,000 signatures on a petition to remove the ads. The Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints, and Transport for London (TFL) confirmed the ads would be taken down after the end of the paid three-week period. Despite the backlash, Protein World defended the campaign, with its head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, arguing it aimed to promote fitness and health. The company also faced threats, including a bomb threat, which are under police investigation. The Advertising Standards Authority is assessing the complaints to determine if further action is needed. The controversy highlights broader debates about body image and the portrayal of women in advertising.

The passage discusses rail firms' plans to implement significant fare hikes, with some increases reaching up to 87%, just ten days after the general election. This move has drawn criticism, especially as both major party leaders had pledged to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has personally intervened, urging First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review its decision to nearly double fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his Witney constituency. Cameron has promised to freeze fares for the next parliament, and Labour has also pledged to cap price hikes. The planned fare increases have angered constituents, leading to Cameron's direct request to FGW. Train companies have three windows annually to increase unregulated fares, which constitute about half of their revenue. FGW has defended the hike, stating it aims to align the North Cotswolds route with other services, while also offering cheaper advanced single tickets. Other notable hikes include a 24.5% increase on an off-peak return between Stafford and Liverpool with Virgin, and a 22% rise on a first-class day return from Manchester to Stoke. Virgin has argued that most of its hikes affect cheaper "Virgin trains-only fares," which are at least 20% cheaper than rival firm tickets, and that its overall fare increase is below the industry average.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after thugs threw a brick through his front door when he confronted them for throwing stones at his property in Oldham. Young and his new wife Elaine, 54, were writing thank you cards for wedding gifts when the attack occurred. The vandals first pelted the front window with stones, breaking the glass, and then threw a brick through the front door, striking Young in the left eye and causing severe injury. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. Young now feels unsafe in his own home and the couple is moving to a different location. Police have launched an investigation but have found no apparent motive, suggesting the attack may have been random vandalism.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a new one-year contract extension after a successful return from injury. Poynton, 25, missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident in which his father Keith died. He underwent ankle surgery but made a comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Poynton will now be available for the start of the season and has committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and hard work in his recovery.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, an aggressive childhood cancer affecting specialized nerve cells. He battled the disease in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. To help him through intensive treatment, including chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley decorated a protective mask with a ninja turtle design, which made him feel stronger. His story gained international attention, earning him recognition from Cancer Research UK and a box of ninja turtle presents from Nickelodeon. After a year-long fight, doctors declared him cancer-free, though he will undergo regular check-ups. His father expressed joy and hope for his return to school full time.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future, emphasizing that Grealish should concentrate on securing a place in the Villa first team. Sherwood was impressed by Grealish's performance in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Grealish is currently being courted by both the Republic of Ireland and England national teams, but Sherwood wants him to play more for Villa before making a decision. Grealish's father, Kevin, also supports this advice, stressing that Grealish should prioritize his club football first. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England by the end of the season, though he is currently undecided.

The passage discusses the issue of high landing fees for private jets, which is a concern mainly for the wealthy who frequently travel by private jet. It highlights that landing fees can vary dramatically across different airports, with some surprising hubs charging the highest fees. Notably, three of the most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo charging the highest at £4,559 ($6,850) per landing. Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo and Kansai International Airport in Osaka. The passage also mentions popular private jet routes and events that drive high demand and costs, such as the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix. The private jet industry is a significant market, worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe.

The passage describes a video featuring Cooper, a Labrador, who quickly eats an ice cream cone at a McDonald's drive-thru with his friend Daisy. Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, took the dogs for the treat. While Daisy takes a few licks, Cooper consumes the entire cone in one bite. The video has garnered over seven million views, with mixed reactions from viewers. Gallegos defends the treat, stating Cooper is healthy and an athlete. Another video shows the dogs at Starbucks, where Cooper again quickly finishes a "pup-uccino," a whipped cream beverage.

Kilmarnock's interim manager Gary Locke has been appointed to the role permanently after signing a three-year contract. Locke, previously the manager of Hearts, joined Kilmarnock as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer but took over as manager when Johnston left in February. Since assuming control, Locke has led the team to just one loss in seven games. He will address the press on Friday morning and officially signed the deal with chairman Jim Mann.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp from Eustis, has accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because of essential oils he uses to help manage his condition. Teachers claimed the oils, manufactured by Doterra, were a distraction and smelled unpleasant to other students. Despite this, Jessica believes the oils help Logan stay calm and focused. Although a teacher's aide complained, Jessica insists she will continue to use the oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood. The school board had stated the oils created a problem, but the Lake County School District later clarified that Logan would not be suspended, considering it a health issue.

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was completely destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze spread through 90 condos, causing the building to collapse. The fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings and smoke was visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews were deployed but were unable to enter the summer homes due to the strength of the flames. Residents, including the building manager, were distraught and reported losing everything. The fire's origin is under investigation, with claims it may have started near a parked car. The Sandpiper Complex is typically used as a holiday home by residents from May to November.

The passage provides a detailed account of the Queen's enduring love for horses, particularly ponies, and her recent riding activities despite her age. The Queen, who is approaching her 89th birthday, was seen riding her faithful black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. Despite being encouraged to wear a helmet for safety, she prefers to ride with a silk scarf due to her hair. The Queen has a long history with horses, starting at age four with a Shetland pony named Peggy. Over the years, she has owned various horses, including Betsy and Surprise. Although she has reduced her riding due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian and takes an active interest in her horses and ponies, which are bred at her Hampton Court and Balmoral stables. The passage also highlights the history and characteristics of fell ponies, a breed that the Queen breeds and rides.

A tragic incident occurred between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels, resulting in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman and the manslaughter charge against 28-year-old Phillip Pama. Yeaman was reportedly making loud noise in his yard when Pama confronted him. The confrontation escalated, and Pama allegedly struck Yeaman with a single punch, causing his death. Paramedics were unable to revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama, a shift worker and father of three, was granted conditional bail and ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to the police twice a week. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, wanted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (approximately £1,400) for the hit, requesting that the boy be tortured and slowly bleed to death. Police set up a sting operation, sending an undercover officer to pose as a hitman. A hidden camera captured Simonova detailing her gruesome instructions, including breaking the boy's arms and legs and damaging his kidneys. After handing over some money, Simonova was arrested in her car. She now faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief and hoped Simonova would have a harsh prison sentence.

The passage provides insights into Chelsea football manager José Mourinho's personal life and faith. It highlights that Mourinho talks to God daily but never discusses football, either with God or his wife, Matilde Faria. He emphasizes his strong faith and daily prayers, though he does not attend church regularly except when in Portugal. Mourinho also mentions his family's background with poverty and their work as ambassadors against hunger for the World Food Programme. He asserts that he tries to separate his professional and family life and considers himself a good family person and friend, despite his competitive nature in football. The passage also notes Mourinho's recent fine by football authorities and mentions his son celebrating a Chelsea victory.

In a notable return after eight years, Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, appeared on the April 1 edition of the show. At 91 years old and looking spry, Barker hosted the first game, the classic "Lucky Seven," before handing over to Drew Carey, who completed the show. Despite his absence from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker appeared to handle his hosting duties effortlessly.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday at 12:30 am for allegedly attempting to break into a house on the 3200 block of D Street SE. Baldwin faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Metropolitan Police apprehended him near the scene of the alleged crime. The Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin was assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which handles diplomatic activities for the State Department. Baldwin was scheduled for arraignment on the same day but no attorney information was available. This incident follows another case where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave for misconduct, and both cases are under investigation by the Homeland Security Department's Inspector General, along with another incident involving two high-ranking officials driving into a secure area at the White House after drinking.

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion in the city's safari park. Saeed crept to within 10 feet of the lion, armed only with a camera, and managed to take a few frames before the shutter sound alerted the lion, forcing him to retreat quickly. He described the encounter as a close one and admitted he wouldn't do it again.

The New York City Police Department has released an image of a distinctive tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman who died in Brooklyn nearly a month ago. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Paramedics were unable to revive her, and she was pronounced dead. The tattoo, located on her right leg, depicts a heart with the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon, topped with a rose. The NYPD is seeking information to identify her and is asking anyone with details to contact Crime Stoppers. The cause of her death is still pending a medical examiner's report.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, returned from the UK and couldn't afford to buy property, so they built a home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck. After a year and a half of work, they created a solar-powered, two-bedroom home made of wood and steel in Nelson, New Zealand. The house is nearly self-sufficient, with solar panels for most electricity, a wood-fired stove, and water from a nearby spring. The project cost around $25,000, and they even plan to build another one someday. The home includes stained glass windows and is surrounded by nature.

The passage highlights research findings by Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University indicating that kindergarten children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who do not use iPads or who use them individually. The study, involving 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district, found that shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher than both individual iPad users and non-iPad users. Blackwell suggests that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just collaboration itself, made the difference. Despite skepticism from the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers about using technology in non-IT classes, Blackwell recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in early grades, to maximize their effectiveness. Blackwell is set to present these findings at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

The passage describes a remarkable piglet that has become an internet sensation due to its ability to walk on just two front legs. Born without hind legs, the piglet has learned to balance and move by foraging with its snout on the ground. The heartwarming video showing its unsteady but determined steps has captured the hearts of many. Despite occasional near falls, the piglet always regains its balance and interacts happily with its siblings, who all have four legs. The piglet belongs to Ms. Duan from Qionglai City in Sichuan Province, China, where villagers have gathered to see the unique animal. This story echoes similar instances in China where animals with unusual abilities have gained popularity, such as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that learned to walk on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone, who had come in on lap 25 for tires and fuel, spun while exiting the pit box and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, received stitches for a leg cut, and was later released. Dracone did not finish the race and finished 23rd. Many cars struggled with traction due to rain before the race.

A disturbing CCTV video shows Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdering his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Severiano confessed that he attacked and shot his wife because he was jealous of men looking at her. The CCTV footage captured him dragging her unconscious body into their garden, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, and punching her face 10 more times before shooting her five times at close range. Neighbors heard an argument before the gunshots. After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was apprehended by police after a crash. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life imprisonment.

In a candid interview, Sarah Wilson, author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," shared her personal struggle with mental illness, revealing that she came close to taking her own life. Wilson, 41, explained how anxiety drove her to believe she had reached a point where she couldn't see the point of continuing. She felt isolated and alone, attributing her mental health issues to a combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family. Wilson believes that acknowledging the intrinsic link between depression and anxiety is crucial to addressing the increasing rate of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. She now sees anxiety as the "new depression" and encourages seeking help if needed, referencing the Beyond Blue and Lifeline helplines.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven months pregnant at the time, will no longer face prosecution for assaulting her boyfriend's former girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin found the ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom, asked her to leave, and when she refused, Curtin struck her with a crowbar. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law permits the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave. Curtin's defense highlighted the ex-girlfriend's history of harassment and attempts to drag Curtin's boyfriend back into addiction. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years. Curtin has since given birth and is living with her parents, while her boyfriend, who has not been involved in his child's life, has reconciled with the ex-girlfriend.

The passage describes Gemma, a pit bull in California, who is filmed at home being fed treats. To trick her, her owner adds a broccoli spear to the treats. Gemma immediately shows disgust upon tasting the broccoli, spits it out on the floor, and serves as a cautionary example for the children she lives with. The passage also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family when she's not eating.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link led to images of women posing naked or having sex when accessed through the bank's page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which was shut down in 2011. The porn site took over the address after the awards were scrapped and the organizers allowed its registration to retire. HSBC removed the hyperlink and denied any association with the external site, offering an apology for any inconvenience caused. The bank assured that its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, provided crucial instructions to firefighters during a 911 call after a fire broke out in his home in Clinton on Sunday morning. Marcus and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom due to the intense heat. Marcus stayed calm throughout the 11-minute call, directing the dispatcher on how to reach them and comforting his sister when she panicked. Firefighters eventually rescued both siblings by breaking a window to enter the room. The three other family members escaped on their own. Marcus and Aaliyah were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the others were taken to Medstar Hospital.

The passage describes amazing pictures of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the neon glow illuminating a popular beach, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene." The phenomenon is caused by millions of plankton called Noctiluca scintillans, which emit light as a defense mechanism. This type of algae, which preys on another type of algae called diatoms, typically blooms in the spring and autumn due to natural causes. A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and an expert from the University of New South Wales assured there is no need for concern about the algae.

The passage discusses how new genetic tests can help breast cancer patients avoid chemotherapy. These tests identify specific genetic markers in the tumor to determine its aggressiveness. After surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab for screening, allowing women to know within days if they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some women, the risk of recurrence is as low as five percent, comparable to or better than the odds for those undergoing chemotherapy. While chemotherapy is routinely given to most breast cancer patients post-surgery to prevent recurrence, it comes with severe side effects. However, experts believe that for some women, chemotherapy may not be necessary due to a lower risk of recurrence. The new test, called EndoPredict, can show a low score, allowing patients to opt out of chemotherapy. These tests are currently available privately at a cost of about £2,500, but there is hope they may become available on the NHS. Surgeons and breast specialists argue that the cost of the test is offset by the savings from not administering chemotherapy. A patient's story illustrates how the test helped her avoid chemotherapy, which she dreaded more than surgery, due to its potential impact on her ability to care for her children.

The passage reveals that over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy. Notably, HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors airlifted in emergency medevacs over the last nine years. At least one woman was also airlifted from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty," before its decommissioning. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations for pregnant women. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, implying the women conceived before boarding or during leave. This data comes after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back following allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan upon discovering their pregnancies, with strict military rules preventing expectant mothers from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's prime minister's residence in Tokyo. The drone had a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing traces of cesium, a byproduct of nuclear reactors. The discovery coincided with a court approval for restarting two reactors at the Sendai Nuclear Power Plant, a move opposed by many due to the Fukushima disaster. Authorities are concerned about potential terrorism involving drones, especially with upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports but lacks similar restrictions in most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was not in his office at the time of the discovery; he was in Indonesia for the Asian-African Conference.

A security guard from China, Lu Xincai, has garnered widespread admiration for his dedication to caring for his 84-year-old mother who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. Lu takes his mother to work on the back of his motorbike every day, tying a sash around both of their waists to ensure her safety. He fears she may get lost if left at home alone, a concern stemming from her past experiences of getting lost while collecting firewood. After the death of his father, Lu decided to bring his mother to work since no one else could care for her. His wife works in a different city, and his son is still in school. At work, Lu checks on his mother, who has been given her own room by his employers at a bank, to ensure she hasn't wandered off. Lu feels a duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to raising him and his siblings.

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, largely driven by rising rates among women. Binge drinking, defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion, also saw significant increases, especially among women. The study noted that in Santa Clara County, California, women's binge drinking rates rose by nearly 36% between 2002 and 2012, compared to 23% among men. The research suggests that changing social norms are making it more acceptable for women to drink heavily, similar to men. Despite these increases, the overall percentage of people drinking any alcohol has remained relatively stable. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers, and 18% were binge drinkers. Public health experts attribute the rise in excessive drinking to cultural shifts, economic factors, and weakened alcohol control policies.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting women and their babies at risk. The World Health Organisation (WHO) advises that caesareans should only be carried out when medically necessary due to the risks of infections and death. Currently, over a quarter of women in England have caesareans, more than double the rate from the early 1990s, partly due to women opting for planned caesareans out of fear of natural childbirth. WHO recommends the caesarean rate should ideally be between 10% and 15% due to associated dangers and costs. Planned caesareans cost the NHS £2,369 on average, compared to £1,665 for natural births. This advice contradicts current NHS guidelines that offer the procedure even without medical justification, including for women with anxiety about childbirth or previous complicated births.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 for allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owner's items in a yard sale. She was discovered by the homeowner, Mark Conklin, in his $800,000 summer home in Edgartown. Filkins claimed ownership of the house before fleeing in a gray Nissan pickup truck when Conklin called the police. She was later arrested after attempting to re-enter the home. Filkins faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Items stolen include furniture, a grill, and a painting. Police are requesting anyone who bought these items to return them and are offering assistance for restitution. Anyone with information should contact the Edgartown Police Department.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was returned to its owner after Albury police on the NSW-Victoria border posted a series of humorous and bizarre selfies and photos on Bella's Facebook page to track her down. The phone was handed in on Sunday morning and, since it was unlocked, officers posted selfies and puns on her Facebook, including photos of the phone in a "holding cell" and assuring her it was safe. Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party and was unaware of the police's efforts until she arrived at the police station. Officers recognized Bella from her Facebook page and she reclaimed her phone without needing to give her name. The police's humorous approach was well-received by Bella and her friends, who labeled the officers "legends." Bella has since added a password to her phone.

The passage describes a tragic incident in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in Eastern South Africa, where a five-day-old baby hippo was caught in a fight between two adult male hippos. The helpless calf strayed into the line of conflict and was thrown into the air by one of the fighting adults. The calf's mother watched in horror as the baby was then dragged along the water's surface and ultimately died from its injuries hours later. The mother tried to intervene but was unable to save her calf. The incident was witnessed by Stacey Farrell, a tour operator, who described the scene with horror. The exact cause of the calf's death remains uncertain, whether due to intended killing, play, or jealousy.

A three-bedroom apartment in the expensive Knightsbridge area of London is on sale for £575,000, significantly less than neighboring homes. However, the property has only three years left on its lease, which could cost around £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, comparable to rental rates in the area. The property, described as "bright and well proportioned" with 1,990 sq/ft, requires modernization and includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, a utility room, a lift, parking, and a communal garden. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The current freeholder is the Wellcome Trust, and extending the lease to 90 years could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. The property is one of two maisonettes on Egerton Place, with the other listed for £595,000. Both properties have short leases and require modernization.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing disruptions at registers and prompting baristas to give away free drinks. The outage, which began on the east coast in the evening and on the west coast in the late afternoon, was resolved by the next day. The company did not specify the exact cause but mentioned it was due to a failure during a daily system refresh. Despite the outage, some stores closed early to avoid giving away free products. Customers took advantage of the situation, leading to widespread sharing of free drink photos on Twitter. Starbucks apologized for the inconvenience and assured customers that operations would return to normal. The outage occurred just a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

The passage highlights that terrorists are training in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. An officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit revealed that these locations are being used to radicalize Muslims. Detective Constable Gareth Jones emphasized that while these individuals participate in ordinary community activities, they have hidden motives. Historical instances of extremist activities in Wales date back to 1998, with more recent cases involving individuals linked to significant terrorist plots. Community intelligence is stressed as vital for authorities to combat these threats.

A juvenile female Omura's whale, feared to be extinct, was found on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, it was confirmed as an Omura's whale through DNA profiling. The find is significant for whale scientists as very little is known about the species, which was first described in scientific journals in 2003 and is usually found in Indonesian, Philippine, and Japanese waters. The carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton for further scientific study and potential public display in museums. Omura's whales have a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae.

The passage discusses the controversial views of Cheryl Rios, the CEO of Go Ape Marketing, who believes that women's hormones make them unfit for leadership roles, specifically citing Hillary Clinton as an example. Rios's comments have sparked significant backlash, highlighting a broader issue of gender bias in leadership. The passage contrasts Rios's views with scientific evidence showing that women leaders tend to take fewer unnecessary risks compared to their male counterparts. It also points out the historical instances of male leaders whose decisions were impaired by their hormones. The passage emphasizes that the real issue is not hormones but the deep-seated gender bias that hinders women's advancement in politics and the workplace. It concludes by stressing the benefits of gender equality for society, the economy, and families, and calls for an end to the bias that prevents women from achieving their full potential.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is auctioning his extensive collection of antiques, valued at £100,000, to downsize his home. The auction, featuring over 200 items, includes a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, early Victorian furniture by Gillows, a medieval longbow, and a portrait of Hardy with the bow. The auction will also include dozens of antique books, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. The sale will take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, on Saturday. Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, expressed sadness at parting with his collection but hopes the new owners will find as much joy in it as he has.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted by authorities as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead in their Winter Garden home. He has been on the run since Saturday after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was discovered. An out-of-state family member made a well-being check that led to the discovery of foul play. Shemansky has a history of mental illness, including a previous commitment for attempted suicide, and was on parole for battery on law enforcement. His estranged wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors suggest that the stress of his ongoing divorce may have contributed to the incident. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not disclosed the method of Sandra Shemansky's death. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without any provisions or medication. Anyone with information on his whereabouts should contact authorities.

The city of Eugene, United States, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council made this decision by bypassing the usual bidding process due to what it viewed as a "unique strategic opportunity to host the IAAF World Championships for the first time in the USA." Eugene had previously lost its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. However, a recent presentation to the IAAF convinced the governing body that Eugene had the necessary capabilities to stage the championships. IAAF President Lamine Diack highlighted the strategic importance of this decision, emphasizing the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public in Eugene. This decision deviates from the standard procedure but was deemed crucial for the global development of the sport. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

Aspiring model Leonie Granger, 25, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter after setting a honey trap to lure professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death. Granger, who spotted Hassan flashing cash at a London casino, used her looks to befriend him, gaining his trust and receiving gifts and cash. On the night of the murder, she left Hassan's flat unlocked, allowing her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler to enter, tie him up, and kick him to death while searching for his hidden winnings. The attack was described by Judge William Kennedy as "pitiless and wicked." Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and received life sentences with a minimum term of 36 years. Granger was convicted of manslaughter but acquitted of murder, with her defense attributing her involvement to her love for Jackson and influence by Chandler.

The passage discusses the declining form of Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas, particularly in the latter half of the season. Fabregas, who had a promising start to the season and was on track to break the Barclays Premier League record for assists, has struggled significantly since Christmas. His poor performance was evident in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland, where he was rated poorly by a Spanish newspaper. Despite his happiness about playing almost every minute for Chelsea, the intense campaign is taking a toll on him. Fabregas' form decline has raised questions about his durability, especially as Chelsea is in a tight race for the Premier League title. His former club Barcelona noted his traditional post-Christmas slump, and Fabregas himself has only one assist in his last five games. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping Fabregas can regain his form to help secure the Premier League title, with Fabregas providing an assist in Chelsea's recent win over Hull City as a potential sign of his resurgence.

West Ham United is negotiating a deal to sign Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old talent from Montego Bay United who impressed during a trial period earlier this month. Beckford, considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean, has also received offers from clubs in Belgium. In addition, West Ham plans to offer the cheapest season tickets in the Barclays Premier League at the Olympic Stadium, starting at £289 for the 2016-17 season to attract more fans.

The police have halted an investigation into a severe assault on Mike Lane, the 40-year-old joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, despite having substantial evidence, including a video and a dossier with names and car registration numbers of the saboteurs. Lane, who was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, was hospitalized with concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Wiltshire Police have stopped the investigation due to insufficient evidence, a decision that has angered Lane and other hunt supporters. Lane expressed disappointment, stating that the police could have done more, and he is losing trust in them. The police have indicated that the case will be reopened if new evidence emerges. The attack occurred on January 24, when about 15 protesters distracted the hounds with citronella, leading to a confrontation where Lane was severely beaten. The main suspect's face was captured on video, but he remains unidentified.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece of Al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, born in 1978, converted to Islam in 1995 and joined Al Qaeda in 1998. He became a prominent English-language propagandist for the group, appearing in videos threatening attacks on the U.S. and Western interests. Gadahn was indicted for treason and material support to Al Qaeda in 2006 and was among the FBI's "Most Wanted Terrorists." He criticized U.S. presidents and urged Muslims to attack American and Western targets. Gadahn's final video in 2014 called for overthrowing governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He was married and had at least one child.

The passage highlights the enthusiasm of Chinese parents in nurturing child prodigies, exemplified by a viral video showcasing five-year-old Mai Zizhuo's impressive basketball skills. Mai has been shooting hoops since he was two and a half years old, and the video shows him skillfully dribbling two basketballs and scoring multiple hoops. His talents have garnered widespread admiration and comments from netizens in China, with many expressing astonishment and even self-deprecation in comparison to his abilities.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) that campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, campaigns against what it perceives as biased press regulation and supports setting up a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. The news of O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off is considered an embarrassment to the group.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as an unconventional catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Models showcased a capsule collection of ten unisex pieces designed to be versatile and worn in 20 different ways, against a backdrop of the ocean. The event attracted crowds who watched from the club's balcony and passersby who stopped to observe from above. Guests enjoyed nibbles from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria while taking in the minimalist, androgynous designs in a sunny, warm day.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a family day at a safari park in northern California, where he posed and fed a rare white tiger, and also took pictures with giraffes and sea lions. He was accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamyssa. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algirri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, whose name appeared on an Israeli memorial wall for fallen soldiers and terror victims, will have his name removed following complaints from his family and others. Abu Khdeir, 16, was brutally murdered by three Israelis in July. His father objected to his inclusion on the memorial, stating he refused to have his son listed among soldiers of the occupation. Almagor, an organization representing terror victims in Israel, also opposed the inclusion, describing Abu Khdeir's death as a rogue attack rather than a terror victim's. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial, has agreed to remove his name following the complaints. The three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing are currently facing a trial.

The passage describes a humorous incident captured on video by California-based YouTube user Lionel Hutz. It shows his young son trying to use the family cat as a pillow to rest his head. The footage depicts the boy chasing the cat around the garden in an attempt to lie down. Initially, the cat allows the boy to rest on him but quickly moves away. The boy then follows the cat to a new spot and repeats the process. This sequence happens twice before the cat finally decides to leave indoors, ending the pillow-chasing game. Later, the video shows the boy making amends with the cat by feeding him treats.

In a police corruption trial in Philadelphia, witness Robert Kushner has lost his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. Kushner, 32, is one of several former drug dealers providing testimony against the accused officers. He claimed that some of the officers on trial stole $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. The school was unaware of this history when they hired Kushner in 2010, despite his passing a background check.
